revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}}
{{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = Albert Horsfall |name = |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = |smallimage = |alt = |caption = |office1 = Founding Director General of the (Nigeria intelligence Agency Director General of the [[State Security Service (Nigeria)|State Security Service]] |term_start1 = 1990 |term_end1 = 1992 |predecessor1 = [[Ismaila Gwarzo]] |successor1 = [[Peter Nwaoduah]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1941|12|22}} |birth_place = [[Rivers State]], Nigeria |death_date = NON }}
''' '''Albert Korubo Horsfall''' is a former Nigerian security chief. Albert Horsfall was born on 22 December 1941 at Buguma in present-day [[Rivers State]]. Horsfall was a police man and pioneer member of the [[National Security Organization]] (NSO). He was also the first [[Director general]] of the [[National Intelligence Agency (Nigeria)|National Intelligence Agency]] (NIA), the fifth Director general of the [[State Security Service (Nigeria)|State Security Service]] (SSS) and the pioneer [[Chairman]] of the Oil Minerals Producing Areas Development Commission (OMPADEC).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1584&Itemid=34 |publisher=Newswatch |title=In the News |author=Pita Ochai;Gift Uwaezuoke |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref>
==Early life== Albert Horsfall grew up in [[Degema, Rivers|Degema]], the administrative headquarters of Degema Division, one of the four divisions that made up the then Rivers Province. Horsfall's father was a successful merchant and he fathered 11 children; three of whom died. Albert left home at the age of seven to live with an uncle, Alex Horsfall, a top civil servant who lived at Degema Consulate. In 1947, Albert began his elementary schooling at Saint Batha School, Degema; he remembers walking from Degema Consulate, then an area populated by expatriates and Nigerian civil servants to his school.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1584&Itemid=34 |publisher=Newswatch |title=In the News |author=Pita Ochai;Gift Uwaezuoke |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/nvnewsthread1/12964/16/ |publisher=NBS News |title=NIGHTLIFE WAS ONCE SAFE – HORSFALL |author= JOSSY IDAM |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref>
In 1951, Horsfall's schooling was disrupted by the death of his uncle Albert in the [[United Kingdom]] while taking in-service training. Albert had to return to his parents in Buguma, where he completed his primary education at Saint Michael's School, Emuohua. In 1959, he graduated from Christ School of Commerce [[Onitsha]], a school owned by his father's friend.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/nvnewsthread1/12964/16/ |publisher=NBS News |title=NIGHTLIFE WAS ONCE SAFE – HORSFALL |author= JOSSY IDAM |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref>
At age 17 in 1962, he joined the [[Nigeria Police Force]] (NPF) for cadet training, but had to wait a year before this could begin. In 1965, he completed his training with the rank of [[Assistant Superintendent]] of Police (ASP). After a brief stint in Abakaliki, Horsfall was selected to join the [[Special Branch]]; at the time, the top three cadet graduates were selected for posting in either the A Department Force [[Headquarters]], the [[Criminal Investigation Department]] (CID), or the [[Special Branch]]. Soon after, Horsfall's boss and Special Branch commissioner, J. J. Sullivan, a retired [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Major]] recognized Horsfall's potential and deployed him to the [[Border control]] unit at [[Enugu]]. At the time, most Nigerian officers in the Special Branch were regarded by the expatriate officers as being more loyal than intelligent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=Why I went into exile during Abacha’s regime |author=Remi Adelowo |accessdate=2012-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415085012/http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |archivedate=15 April 2014 }}</ref>
After Sullivan went on retirement leave, his Nigerian successor, T. H. Fagbola, who needed capable Nigerian officers to work with, assigned Horsfall back to headquarters in [[Lagos]]. Soon after, Horsfall attended an intelligence training course in the [[United States]]. While he was there in 1966, the [[Nigerian Civil War]] broke out. Horsfall, from the southern part of the country, returned to Nigeria on the side of the Federal Government.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=Why I went into exile during Abacha’s regime |author=Remi Adelowo |accessdate=2012-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415085012/http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |archivedate=15 April 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/nvnewsthread1/12964/16/ |publisher=NBS News |title=NIGHTLIFE WAS ONCE SAFE – HORSFALL |author= JOSSY IDAM |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref> At the time, [[General]] [[Yakubu Gowon]]'s government had dissolved the country's four regions—Northern Region, [[Western Region, Nigeria|Western region]], [[Mid-Western Region, Nigeria|Mid-Western Region]], and the [[Eastern Region, Nigeria|Eastern Region]]—into 12 new states. This was calculated to fragment support for the seceding [[Biafra]]n state, which was mostly made up of the Eastern Region and the Mid-Western State. Horsfall's new [[Rivers State]] was formerly part of the Eastern Region, which now sided with the Federal Government in the war.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onlinenigeria.com/military/?blurb=677 |publisher=Online Nigeria |title=The Gowon Regime and The Nigerian Civil War, 1966 - 1975 |author= Online Nigeria |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref>
When Horsfall returned from the [[United States]], the Special Branch was severely short-staffed because of the exodus of easterners to seceding Biafra. This situation thrust a greater workload on him and might in part also account for his rapid rise in the service. Horsfall claims to have been embedded with the federal troops in [[Opobo]], [[Calabar]], [[Onne]], and [[Port Harcourt]]; he obviously would have held some advantage in this role because he was indigenous to the area.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/27676/1/I-once-told-Umaru-DikkoIf-Id-been-involved-in-your-kidnap-you-wouldnthave-been-saved/Page1.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=I once told Umaru Dikko:‘If I'd been involved in your kidnap, you wouldn'thave been saved' |author=AUGUSTINE AVWODE |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 1972, Horsfall married Henrietta. She was one of a couple of young women he had helped move to [[Lagos]] to continue their education during the civil war, and he knew her family. They have seven children.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/27676/1/I-once-told-Umaru-DikkoIf-Id-been-involved-in-your-kidnap-you-wouldnthave-been-saved/Page1.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=I once told Umaru Dikko:‘If I'd been involved in your kidnap, you wouldn'thave been saved' |author=AUGUSTINE AVWODE |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=Why I went into exile during Abacha’s regime |author=Remi Adelowo |accessdate=2012-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415085012/http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |archivedate=15 April 2014 }}</ref>
Horsfall remained with the Special Branch until 1976, when the department was excised from the NPF due to the creation of the [[National Security Organization]] (NSO). Horsfall, by then an [[Assistant Commissioner]] of Police joined the NSO as an officer under the first [[Director-General]], [[Colonel]] [[Abdullahi Mohammed]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/27676/1/I-once-told-Umaru-DikkoIf-Id-been-involved-in-your-kidnap-you-wouldnthave-been-saved/Page1.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=I once told Umaru Dikko:‘If I'd been involved in your kidnap, you wouldn'thave been saved' |author=AUGUSTINE AVWODE |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==National Security and Public Service== Albert Horsfall claims he had always wanted to study law but had not been able to because of the demands of his job. His former bosses at the Special Branch and the NSO, M. D. Yussuf and Abdullahi Mohammed, had refused his applications for a study leave on the grounds he was too useful to their organizations to lose. He eventually left the NSO without official leave to study law in 1979. He was able to do this during the handover period between the outgoing director general, Colonel Abdullahi Mohammed, and the incoming director general, Umaru Shinkafi. Horsfall alleged that Shinkafi was sympathetic to his cause because Shinkafi himself, a former commissioner of police, had also taken leave of the Police to study law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/27676/1/I-once-told-Umaru-DikkoIf-Id-been-involved-in-your-kidnap-you-wouldnthave-been-saved/Page1.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=I once told Umaru Dikko:‘If I'd been involved in your kidnap, you wouldn'thave been saved' |author=AUGUSTINE AVWODE |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Horsfall rose through the ranks of the NSO and eventually became the agency's second deputy director general, replacing Peter Odukwe after he was retired in 1984 during a purge of Shinkafi-era operatives by the new NSO director general, [[Ambassador]] Mohammed Lawal Rafindadi.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nairaland.com/nigeria/topic-612263.0.html |publisher=Nairaland |title=Buhari, politics and History |author= Ebeneezer Babatope |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/50481400/Address-by-de-John-service-Award |publisher=Scribd |title=Address by De John, fcw, Chairman of the 2008 service and end year party held on 20th December 2008 |author= State Security Service |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref> Horsfall held this position till the dissolution of the NSO in 1986 by the new military government headed by [[General]] [[Ibrahim Babangida]]. During his time as NSO deputy director general under Rafindadi, the agency was at its height of notoriety. Political repression was rife, arrest and detention without trial under the infamous Decree 2 (state security; detention of persons) and Decree 4 (press gag) was common.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://digitalizenigeria.com/2011/11/21/trials-and-tribulations-at-the-guardian/ |publisher=Digital Nigeria |title=Trials and tribulations at The Guardian |author=Digital Nigeria |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426062937/http://digitalizenigeria.com/2011/11/21/trials-and-tribulations-at-the-guardian/ |archivedate=26 April 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20089687,00.html |publisher=People Magazine |title=A Bad Deal and Harsh Justice Make An American Businesswoman a Prisoner of Fate in Nigeria |author=Joshua Hammer |accessdate=2011-12-28}}</ref> One of the more notorious actions of the NSO during this period was the "[[Dikko Affair]]." The Dikko Affair was an attempt by the NSO and an Israeli collaborator to kidnap and repatriate second republic [[Transport]] [[Minister (government)|Minister]] [[Alhaji]] [[Umaru Dikko]] from his [[United Kingdom]] exile in 1984. The attempt failed and Nigeria suffered great diplomatic and economic repercussions, Horsfall has denied any involvement in the attempt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenationonlineng.net/web2/articles/27676/1/I-once-told-Umaru-DikkoIf-Id-been-involved-in-your-kidnap-you-wouldnthave-been-saved/Page1.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=I once told Umaru Dikko:‘If I'd been involved in your kidnap, you wouldn'thave been saved' |author=AUGUSTINE AVWODE |accessdate=2012-07-01 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The Babangida government launched investigations into NSO activities under Rafindadi, a Commission of Inquiry headed by former NSO Director General Umaru Shinkafi was also instituted. The security services were reorganised under Decree 19 of 1986, which led to the creation of three agencies: the [[State Security Service (Nigeria)|State Security Service]] (SSS), the [[National Intelligence Agency (Nigeria)|National Intelligence Agency]] (NIA), and the [[Defence Intelligence Agency (Nigeria)|Defence Intelligence Agency]] (DIA). The new government appointed Horsfall the first director general of the NIA. The NIA was responsible for Nigeria's foreign intelligence. Horsfall held this position until 1990, when he replace Alhaji Ismaila Gwarzo as the SSS' fifth director general.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/2001/22012001/COVER501.HTM |publisher=Newswatch Volume 33 No 4 |title=Give Me My Money |author=Olu Ojewale |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63xIrwAp4?url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/editorial/prime/2001/22012001/COVER501.HTM |archivedate=15 December 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/50481400/Address-by-de-John-service-Award |publisher=Scribd |title=Address by De John, fcw, Chairman of the 2008 service and end year party held on 20th December 2008 |author= State Security Service |accessdate=2011-12-29}}</ref>
On 10 October 1992, Horsfall left the SSS. From 1993, he was the first chairman of the Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission (OMPADEC), a special purpose vehicle established by the government to bring about rapid development to the oil-producing [[Niger Delta]]; Horsfall is indigenous to the area.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=Why I went into exile during Abacha’s regime |author=Remi Adelowo |accessdate=2012-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415085012/http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |archivedate=15 April 2014 }}</ref> Horsfall hired [[Goodluck Jonathan]], later a president of Nigeria, for OMPADEC, Jonathan's first public service job. On 22 February 1996, the OMPADEC Board was dissolved. Horsfall and the OMPADEC commissioners were removed based on claims by the Abacha government of widespread non-performance by contractors; the government claimed these contractors received mobilization money but failed to perform satisfactorily. This followed a prolonged campaign of calumny mounted by Dr. Junaid, the fiery advocate of northern supremacy who Horsfall forcefully removed from the OMPADEC Board in 1995. In defence of his role and integrity, Horsfall claimed with authentic figures and statistics from the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) that during his three years of service in OMPADEC, the Commission had received only 11.48 billion naira approximately $133,488,372 from government through monthly disbursements from the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) and that with this paltry sum he had performed a near miracle by dotting the whole of the nine oil-producing states with several on-going, medium and major projects and actually completed and commissioned 102 such projects and put them in use by the various communities throughout those oil-producing states.
Following the OMPADEC Commission's dissolution and the removal of Horsfall and his Board, five different investigation panels probed the allegations of corruption, uncompleted projects, and debts being owed by contractors to OMPADEC. These included a panel headed by the famous anti-corruption crusader Economics Professor Sam Aluko. None of these panels returned a verdict of corruption or improprieties on Horsfall. He returned to normal life, is enjoying his normal pension, and is a legal consultant. He has been chairman or a member of several federal constitutional review bodies, special adviser to President Obasanjo on Niger Delta Development, rehabilitation of militant and delinquent Rivers State youth, a member of the Nigerian National Constitutional Conference 2014, and a member of its special committee of 50 "wise men."
In 1997, he established his law firm, Horsfall and Company.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |publisher=The Nation Newspapers |title=Why I went into exile during Abacha’s regime |author=Remi Adelowo |accessdate=2012-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415085012/http://www.thenationonlineng.net/2011/index.php/sunday-magazine/arts-life/31708-%E2%80%98why-i-went-into-exile-during-abacha%E2%80%99s-regime%E2%80%99.html |archivedate=15 April 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newswatchngr.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1584&Itemid=34 |publisher=Newswatch |title=In the News |author=Pita Ochai;Gift Uwaezuoke |accessdate=2012-07-01}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Andrew Maguire''' is a British commodities trader and whistleblower. He presented evidence to United States regulators alleging that fraud had been committed, and that prices in the international gold and silver markets had been manipulated. No regulatory or legal action has been taken as a result of his accusations.
== Background == On 29 March 2010 he was interviewed on the radio with [[Gold Anti-Trust Action Committee]] (GATA) board member [[Adrian Douglas]].<ref>[http://www.deepcapture.com/tag/commodity-futures-trading-commission/ "Manipulating Gold and Silver: A Criminal Naked Short Position that Could Wreck the Economy"] DeepCapture.com (April 2, 2010). Retrieved May 4, 2011</ref> He went public in April 2010 with assertions of market manipulation by [[JPMorgan Chase]] and [[HSBC]] of the gold and silver markets,<ref name="nyp-whistle" /> prompting a number of lawsuits,<ref name="zh-amlatest" /> including a [[class action lawsuit]].<ref name="nalvensuit">[http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/opinion/Informant_Lawsuit.pdf Eric Nalven class action lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase and HSBC] (PDF) ''The New York Times'' (November 2, 2010). Retrieved May 7, 2011</ref> Maguire said "JPMorgan acts as an agent for the [[Federal Reserve]]; they act to halt the rise of gold and silver against the US dollar. JPMorgan is insulated from potential losses (on their [[Short (finance) | short ]] [[Position (finance)|positions]]) by the Fed and/or the U.S. taxpayer." "No one at JPMorgan is familiar with Andrew Maguire," said Brian Marchiony, a JPMorgan spokesman. HSBC declined to comment.<ref name="nyp-whistle" /> Maguire was not a former [[Goldman Sachs]] trader as has often been reported although he did work briefly for J. Aron & Co. which was acquired by Goldman Sachs in 1981.<ref name="nyp-whistle">Michael Gray, [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/metal_are_in_the_pits_2arTlGNbMK7mb1uJeVHb0O/0#ixzz0nZh8WLBC "Ex-Goldman trader blows whistle on silver and gold manipulation by JPMorgan, HSBC"] ''New York Post'' (April 11, 2010). Retrieved May 5, 2011</ref><ref name="zh-amlatest">[http://www.zerohedge.com/article/andrew-maguire-re-emerges-ex-goldman-trader-exposes-jpmorgan-hsbc-latest-silver-price-manipu "Andrew Maguire Re-Emerges: Ex-Goldman Trader Exposes JPMorgan, HSBC In Latest Silver Price Manipulation Class Action Lawsuit"] [[Zero Hedge]] (November 9, 2010). Retrieved May 6, 2011</ref><ref name="maguire response">Andrew Maguire, [http://www.silverdoctors.com/a-formal-response-from-andrew-maguire/ "A Formal Response from Andrew Maguire"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031170910/http://www.silverdoctors.com/a-formal-response-from-andrew-maguire/ |date=2013-10-31 }} ''Silver Doctors'' (October 29, 2013). Retrieved October 29, 2013</ref>
== Market Manipulation == In an interview with CBC aired in April 2013 Andrew Maguire described how mysterious traders, allegedly working for [[bullion banks]] [[JPMorgan Chase|JPMorgan]] and to a lesser extent [[HSBC]], waited for most of the major markets from Shanghai to London to be closed then concentrated their dealing on [[New York Mercantile Exchange|COMEX]]. He explained how traders were trading virtual or electronic silver anonymously using [[algorithmic trading|algorithmic trading systems]] "moving in and out of the futures markets in the blink of an eye. Four hundred contracts a second, each contract represents 5,000 troy ounces of silver." Maguire described a sudden and massive wave of selling of up to 45,000 contracts which drove the price of silver down. "Investors big and small try to cut their losses and sell as the price drops." People who had invested heavily lost everything. Then the mysterious seller just as suddenly started buying the electronic silver again. The price of silver soared as did profits for the seller. 45,000 contracts with a profit of $80,000 per contract totaled $3,600,000,000 for the mystery seller.<ref name=CBCSecretGold2013> {{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/doczone/episode/the-secret-world-of-gold.html?subpage=infographic |publisher=CBC |first=Brian |last=McKenna |first2=Ann-Marie |last2=MacDonald |title=The Secret World Of Gold |date=21 April 2013 }}</ref>
According to Maguire, the precious metals markets trade "pretty much in tandem", but because the silver market is so much smaller, it is harder to disguise one's activities and therefore easier to figure out who is behind a manipulative event.<ref name="interview">Eric King, [http://www.kingworldnews.com/kingworldnews/Broadcast/Entries/2010/3/30_Andrew_Maguire_%26_Adrian_Douglass.html Interview with Andrew Maguire and GATA board member Adrian Douglas] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615151821/http://www.kingworldnews.com/kingworldnews/Broadcast/Entries/2010/3/30_Andrew_Maguire_%26_Adrian_Douglass.html |date=2011-06-15 }} [[King World News]] (March 30, 2010). Retrieved May 6, 2011</ref> After [[Bear Stearns]] and their short silver positions were acquired by JPMorgan, manipulative events in the silver market became more frequent. Maguire decided to inform the CFTC. He contacted commissioner [[Bart Chilton]], who had Eliud Ramirez, a senior investigator from the CFTC's enforcement division, get in touch with Maguire.<ref name="interview" /><ref>Lawrence Williams, [http://www.mineweb.com/mineweb/view/mineweb/en/page72068?oid=101525&sn=Detail "GATA's evidence of silver and gold manipulation at CFTC hearing"] Mineweb (March 26, 2010). Retrieved May 11, 2011</ref> Maguire explained the manipulations in great detail, both over the phone in an hour-long interview and afterward, in a series of e-mails with [[screen shot]]s.<ref name="interview" />
Maguire then predicted a manipulative event in the silver market and gave detailed information in an e-mail to the CFTC about what to expect, sending it on 3 February 2010, two days prior to the event. The event transpired exactly as Maguire predicted.<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/20100405/silver-prices-are-easy-manipulate-nia.htm Silver prices are easy to manipulate: NIA] ''International Business Times'' (April 5, 2010). Retrieved May 5, 2011</ref><ref name="kwn-emails">[http://www.kingworldnews.com/kingworldnews/G+_Articles/Entries/2010/3/30_A_LONDON_TRADER_WALKS_THE_CFTC_THROUGH_A_SILVER_MANIPULATION_IN_ADVANCEBy_Andrew_Maguire.html E-mail exchange between Maguire and the CFTC] King World News (January 26, 2010 - February 9, 2010). Retrieved May 4, 2011</ref> While the event was taking place, Maguire sent e-mails in [[Real-time business intelligence|real time]], pointing out certain details because the CFTC enforcement seemed not to know what to look for or how to interpret the data.<ref name="interview" />
GATA chairman [[Bill Murphy (GATA chairman)|Bill Murphy]] gave a detailed account of Maguire's allegations to the [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] (CFTC), stating how "JP Morgan Chase signals to the market its intention to take down the precious metals. Traders recognize these signals and make money [[shorting]] the metals alongside JPMorgan. [He] explained how there are routine [[market manipulation]]s at the time of option expiry, non-farm payroll data releases, and COMEX contract rollover, as well as the ''ad hoc'' events."<ref>[http://www.thestreet.com/story/10753883/2/silver-price-manipulation-investigation-focused-on-jpmorgan-chase.html Silver Price Manipulation Investigation Focused On JPMorgan Chase] TheStreet.com (May 11, 2010). Retrieved May 5, 2011</ref>
==Ongoing criminal investigation== The [[United States Department of Justice]]'s Antitrust Division and the CFTC are conducting civil and criminal probes stemming from a ''[[New York Post]]'' article concerning Maguire's allegations.<ref name="nyp-fedprobe">Michael Gray, [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/feds_probing_jpmorgan_trades_in_gZzMvWBqOJpB55M7Rh9vwM?sms_ss=email "Feds probing JPMorgan trades in silver pit"] ''New York Post'' (May 9, 2010). Retrieved May 5, 2011</ref> Following publication of the article, JPMorgan released a statement that they are not under investigation by the Department of Justice or the CFTC.<ref name="nyp-fedprobe" /> The CFTC has interviewed 32 people and reviewed 40,000 documents, but as of May 2011, no action has been taken.<ref name="nyt">William D. Cohan, [http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/02/a-conspiracy-with-a-silver-lining/ "A Conspiracy With a Silver Lining"] ''The New York Times'' (March 2, 2011). Retrieved May 7, 2011</ref> On 24 February 2011, in less than an hour, the price of silver fell $1.50 per ounce before recovering.<ref name="nyt" /> Another London-based trader, Richard Guthrie, wrote to Chilton to complain about the event, asking “How many investors lost money and positions to the financial benefit of an elite few?”<ref name="nyt" /> Chilton believes violations of the law have taken place and wants to see prosecutions move forward,<ref name="nyt" /> but the five-member commission has yet to act.
== See also == * [[Gold as an investment]] * [[Regulatory capture]] * [[Silver as an investment]] * ''[[Inside Job (2010 film)|Inside Job]]'' – [[Academy Award]]-winning documentary about "the [[systemic corruption]] of the United States by the financial services industry and the consequences of that systemic corruption"<ref>[[Charlie Rose]], [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vS0hj4kiqsA Interview with filmmaker Charles Ferguson] YouTube video (February 25, 2011). Retrieved March 14, 2011</ref> * [[List of whistleblowers]]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{refimprove|date=July 2009}} '''Aro''' (known only by that name) was the [[List of most recent executions by jurisdiction|last person executed]] in [[Papua New Guinea]].[http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2007/s2087787.htm "PNG urged to abandon death penalty"], Australian Broadcasting Corporation, 12 November 2007 In 1957, [[History of Papua New Guinea#The Territory of Papua and New Guinea|while Papua New Guinea was an Australian territory]], Aro, then a young man, walked into a hospital "carrying a baby and a blood-stained axe" and stated that he had killed his two wives. He was convicted of willful murder, sentenced to death, and executed by [[hanging]] in November 1957. There were no further executions. The death penalty was abolished in 1970, five years before Papua New Guinea's independence from Australia. It was reintroduced in 1991, but never applied. ==See also== * [[List of most recent executions by jurisdiction]] * [[Use of capital punishment by nation#Oceania]] ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Brahim Hemdani | fullname = Ibrahim Hemdani | image = Brahim Hemdani, Nou Camp.JPG | image_size = 180 | caption = Hemdani playing for [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] in November 2007 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1978|3|15|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Colombes]], France | height = {{height|m=1.80}} | position = [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|Defensive midfielder]] | youthclubs1 = [[Racing Club de France football Colombes 92|Racing Paris]] | youthyears1 = 1996–1997 | years1 = 1997–1998 | years2 = 1998–2001 | years3 = 2001–2005 | years4 = 2005–2009 | clubs1 = [[AS Cannes|Cannes]] | clubs2 = [[RC Strasbourg|Strasbourg]] | clubs3 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | clubs4 = [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] | caps1 = 27 | goals1 = 1 | caps2 = 53 | goals2 = 3 | caps3 = 95 | goals3 = 1 | caps4 = 67 | goals4 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2008–2009 | nationalteam1 = [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 }}
'''Brahim Hemdani''' (born 15 March 1978 in [[Colombes]], [[Hauts-de-Seine]]) is a retired [[Algeria]]n professional [[football (soccer)|footballer]].
==Club career== Hemdani started his career with [[AS Cannes|Cannes]], where he spent two seasons. He later transferred to [[RC Strasbourg]], spending three seasons with the club. He then joined [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]], which he helped reach the [[UEFA Cup]] final in [[2004 UEFA Cup Final|2004]].
Hemdani then joined Rangers on 14 June 2005 on a [[Bosman transfer]] and signed a four-year contract.<ref name="Rangers transfer">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/4090958.stm | publisher=BBC Sport website | title=Rangers clinch deal for Hemdani | date=14 June 2005}}</ref> He suffered from injury problems during his first season, waiting until late October to make his debut against [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee United]].<ref name="Dundee Utd 0-0 Rangers ">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/4338832.stm | publisher=BBC Sport website | title=Dundee Utd 0-0 Rangers | date=16 October 2005}}</ref> Hemdani was a regular in the side from then on and helped the club reach the last 16 of the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] for the first time in their history. The season ended with the side finishing third in the league and trophyless. The following summer, [[Paul Le Guen]] took over as manager and Hemdani began the [[2006–07 in Scottish football|2006–07]] season in [[midfielder|midfield]] but was moved to the [[defender (football)|centre of defence]].
Hemdani scored his first goal for Rangers midway through that season, a shot from outside the box to equalise in the 88th minute of an [[Old Firm]] game on 17 December 2006.<ref name="Rangers 1-1 Celtic">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/scot_prem/6177705.stm | publisher=BBC Sport| title=Rangers 1-1 Celtic | date=17 December 2006}}</ref> His second goal came in similar circumstances in a [[UEFA Cup 2006-07|UEFA Cup]] match in March 2007, against [[CA Osasuna]], scoring to equalise in injury time.<ref name="Rangers 1-1 Osasuna ">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/6415057.stm | publisher=BBC Sport| title=Rangers 1-1 Osasuna | date=8 March 2007}}</ref>
On 16 April 2007, Hemdani was named Rangers Player of the Year at an award ceremony, voted for by the club's fans.<ref name="Player of the Year">{{cite news|url=http://www.rangers.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Headlines/0,,5~1011888,00.html |title=Hemdani Named Player Of The Year |publisher=Rangers official website |date=16 April 2007 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He made his 100th appearance for [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] on 13 March 2008 in a [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]] match against [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]],<ref name="Hemdani 100">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/7285148.stm|title=W Bremen 1-0 Rangers (agg 1-2) |publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 March 2008}}</ref> the club went on to reach [[2008 UEFA Cup Final|the final that season]], which Hemdani played the full 90 minutes of. However, this turned out to be his last match for Rangers as the [[Rangers F.C. season 2008-09|2008-09 season]] saw Hemdani frozen out of the first team. He left on 1 June 2009 having made a total of 108 appearances and scoring twice.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/8077300.stm|title=Weir poised for new Rangers deal |date=1 June 2009|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==International career== Hemdani declined the chance to be included as part of the Algeria national squad on several occasions in the past.<ref name="Players reject Algeria">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/3570178.stm| title=Players reject Algeria | publisher=BBC Sport website| date=16 August 2004}}</ref> However, in February 2008 he had a change of heart and decided to play for [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]].<ref name="Brahim Hemdani Has World Cup Dream With Algeria">{{cite news | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football-news/2008/02/08/brahim-hemdani-has-world-cup-dream-with-algeria-86908-20312646/| title=Brahim Hemdani Has World Cup Dream With Algeria | publisher=Daily Record| date=8 February 2008}}</ref> Hemdani made his [[Algeria national football team|Algerian]] debut in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification|2010 World Cup qualifier]] against [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] on 31 May 2008.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/7429606.stm "Senegal 1-0 Algeria"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419122641/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/7429606.stm |date=19 April 2012 }} BBC Sport website (31 May 200)8</ref>
==Career statistics==

revision.text:
'''Carl Wittman''' (February 23, 1943 – January 22, 1986) was a member of the national council of [[Students for a Democratic Society (SDS)]] and later an activist for LGBT rights. He co-authored "An Interracial Movement of the Poor?" (1963) <ref>Hayden, Tom and Wittmann, Carl [http://www.sds-1960s.org/Interracial-Movement-Poor.pdf ''Students for a Democratic Society Archive''] [[Wisconsin State Historical Society]] (1963) Retrieved August 2, 2011.</ref> with [[Tom Hayden]] and wrote "A Gay Manifesto" <ref name="A Gay Manifesto">Wittman, Carl [http://paganpressbooks.com/jpl/TRB-WITT.PDF ''A Gay Manifesto''] A Red Butterfly Publication, New York. (1970) Retrieved August 2, 2011.</ref> (1970). Wittman declined hospital treatment for [[AIDS]] and committed suicide by drug overdose at home in North Carolina.<ref name="who?">{{cite web|last1=Highleyman|first1=Liz|title=Who was Carl Wittman?|url=http://www.sgn.org/sgnnews34_18/page30.cfm|website=Seattle Gay News|accessdate=March 22, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170422030509/http://www.sgn.org/sgnnews34_18/page30.cfm|archivedate=April 22, 2017|df=}}</ref>
== Early activism ==
In 1960, Wittman entered [[Swarthmore College]] where he became a student activist. Wittman spent summers doing civil rights work in the South, and joined the national council of Students for a Democratic Society (SDS). In 1966, after becoming disillusioned with homophobia in the [[New Left]], Wittman left SDS. Wittman married Mimi Feingold the same year.<ref name="who?" />
In 1967, Wittman moved to San Francisco with Feingold where they lived with other activists in an anti-draft commune. Wittman turned in his draft card to the Oakland Induction Center in October 1967 during Stop the Draft Week.
== Gay activism ==
Wittman, while self-identified as gay since the age of 14, remained closeted until coming out in the late 1960s in an article, "Waves of Resistance," published in the November, 1968 issue of the antiwar magazine, ''[[Liberation (magazine)|Liberation]]''.<ref>Wittman, Carl. [https://books.google.com/books?id=dLYqAQAAIAAJ&q=%22waves+of+resistance%22+wittman&dq=%22waves+of+resistance%22+wittman&hl=en&ei=Hnw4Tu_AA6fX0QG93uzOAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCA ''Waves of Resistance''] ''Synergy Magazine'' Vol 13-30, [[San Francisco Public Library]]. Retrieved August 2, 2011.</ref><ref>Wittman, Carl. [https://www.amazon.com/Waves-resistance-Carl-Wittman/dp/B0007HR1GC ''Waves of Resistance''] pg. 29-33 ''[[Liberation (magazine)|Liberation]]'', New York. (1968) Retrieved August 2, 2011{{dead link |date=March 2016}}</ref>
In 1969, Wittman wrote Refugees from Amerika: A Gay Manifesto published by The Red Butterfly cell of the [[Gay Liberation Front]] January, 1970.<ref name="A Gay Manifesto" /> It is considered one of the most influential gay liberation writings of the 1970s.
{{quote|Exclusive heterosexuality is fucked up. It reflects a fear of people of the same sex, it's anti-homosexual, and it is fraught with frustration. Heterosexual sex is fucked up too; ask women's liberation about what straight guys are like in bed. Sex is aggression for the male chauvinist; sex is obligation for the traditional woman.|Amerika: A Gay Manifesto I.3<ref>{{Cite book|title=Refugees from Amerika: A Gay Manifeso|last=Wittman|first=Carl|publisher=San Francisco Free Press|year=1969|location=San Francisco}}</ref>}}
In 1971, Wittman moved to Wolf Creek, Oregon with his then-partner, Stevens McClave. Two years later, he began a long-term relationship with a fellow war resister, Allan Troxler, a conscientious objector.
In the early 1980s, Wittman created the North Carolina Lesbian and Gay Health Project (LGHP) with David Jolly, Timmer McBride, and Aida Wakil to address the health needs of sexual minorities in that state.<ref>Lekus, Ian K. "Health care, the AIDS crisis, and the politics of community: The North Carolina Lesbian and Gay Health Project, 1982-1996." ''Modern American Queer History'' Allida Black (ed). Philadelphia, PA: Temple University Press, 2001.</ref>
== Instrumental figure in country dance ==
"Carl Wittman, led the development in the United States of a movement diametrically opposed to Kennedy's couples policy: "gender-free" dance in which there were no gendered dance roles" (page 205, of Walkowitz' City Folk)
Carl Whittman, a certified RSCDS (Royal Scottish Country Dance Society) instructor, started teaching Scottish country dancing in the San Francisco area about 1970. Carl was very involved in the gay political movements of that era. In the early 1970s, Carl left San Francisco and traveled up the coast to the artist's community of Wolf Creek, Oregon and eventually settled in Golden, Oregon with his partner, Allan Troxler. Carl became involved in the newly emerging [[intentional community|intentional communities]] of gay men and lesbians in that area. He started a local community dance in his barn in Golden, Oregon, where he pulled in people from these intentional communities, as well as families and friends from around the area. His dancing community ended up being a mixture of amilies, gay men, lesbians and friends. Carl taught English and Scottish country dancing, at first, in the tradition and style in which he had learned, identifying dancers by their gender role and using gender language. He allowed anyone to dance with whomever they wished and in any role they chose, but he used the conventional gender terminology to identify these roles. Sometime thereafter, Alan challenged Carl to change this convention, and come up with something that was more appropriate for their community. Carl changed his role identification system to "Reds" and "Greens" (Reds identifying the traditional gent's position and Greens to identify the lady's position). He went on to further develop this to a method defined as "Left File" and "Right File" dancers (the left file identifying the traditional gent's role and the right file identifying the traditional ladies position). Over time, Carl started traveling around Oregon, starting other dance communities, teaching this style of English and Scottish Country Dancing. Carl developed another tradition during this time, that being of how to line up for each dance. He advocated that everyone come to the set individually and fill in the next available space. This method ensures that everyone will have someone to dance with and addressed the sometimes-awkward practice of asking someone to dance, particularly with folks new to the dance. This method has also been adopted by the Boston gender-free English country dance community with an additional note that if you desire to dance with a particular partner, wait until all spaces in the set are filled above you before coming to the set. Carl was also the dance leader and principal choreographer for the Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, Oregon in 1980.<ref>http://lcfd.org/Articles/GFManual/GF-Manual.pdf</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110927025159/http://www.queertheory.com/histories/w/wittman_carl.htm Brief Biography] * [http://lcfd.org/Articles/GFManual/GF-Manual.pdf] * [http://oregondigital.org/u?/comm,248 Image of Carl Wittman in his house in southern Oregon]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Clive Coates | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1941 | birth_place = Wimbledon, London, UK | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Wine writer | nationality = British | period = | genre = | subject = Wine | movement = | notableworks = | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.clive-coates.com}} }}
'''Clive Coates''' is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[wine]] writer and [[Master of Wine]],<ref>http://www.mastersofwine.org [http://www.mastersofwine.org/en/about/meet-the-masters/profile/index.cfm/id/DC13CC24-BA22-4BA7-9DABAC3F6A29166C Masters of Wine, Clive Coates profile] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125070302/http://mastersofwine.org/en/about/meet-the-masters/profile/index.cfm/id/DC13CC24-BA22-4BA7-9DABAC3F6A29166C |date=2010-11-25 }}</ref> best known for his books about the wines of [[Burgundy wine|Burgundy]].<ref name=OCW-ref>winepros.com.au. {{Cite web|last= ''Oxford Companion to Wine''|title= Reference|url= http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/reference.jsp|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080721121803/http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/reference.jsp|archivedate= 2008-07-21|df= }}</ref>
== Biography == Born in 1941, Clive Coates worked for The Wine Society in [[Stevenage]] in the late 1960s and early 1970s.<ref name="WineSoc">The Wine Society, ''Society News'', Jan/Feb 2007</ref> In 1975 he founded the award-winning magazine ''[[The Vine (magazine)|The Vine]]'',<ref name=OCW-vine>winepros.com.au. {{Cite web|last= ''Oxford Companion to Wine''|title= ''The Vine''|url= http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/TheVine.jsp|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080417235130/http://www.winepros.com.au/jsp/cda/reference/TheVine.jsp|archivedate= 2008-04-17|df= }}</ref><ref name="CC">[http://www.clive-coates.com clive-coates.com] bio</ref> a monthly fine wine journal that ran for 241 issues until ill-health in 2005 forced him to stop. He also wrote a number of classic books about the classic wine regions of France in this time. Despite describing himself as semi retired, he published his latest book, ''The Wines of Burgundy'' in March 2008.<ref name="CC" />
He lives in [[Saint-Bonnet-de-Vieille-Vigne]], between the [[Côte Chalonnaise]] and the [[Mâconnais]].
== Bibliography == He is best known for ''Côte d'Or: A Celebration of the Great Wines of Burgundy'', a survey of the most famous wine producing region of Burgundy covering more than 1000 pages, published in 1997.<ref name=wd-coa>{{Cite web|last= Kissack |first= Chris, thewinedoctor.com|title= Wine Books: Clive Coates |url= http://www.thewinedoctor.com/otherresources/coates.shtml }}</ref> It includes technical information about the vineyards of the [[Côte-d'Or]], details about [[wine making]] techniques employed by hundreds of different producers and [[wine ratings]] of thousands of wines. The new book from 2008 is effectively a revision of this one, but expanded to include all major wine districts of Burgundy,<!-- Maconnais is missing --> and without the in-depth profile of a selected number of producers in the 1997 book.
Other recent books include ''The Wines of Bordeaux'' (2004) and ''The Great Wines of France'' (2005).
== See also == * [[List of wine personalities]] * [[Coates Law of Maturity]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.clive-coates.com Clive Coates official site]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Coates, Clive}} [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Wine critics]] [[Category:Masters of Wine]] [[Category:James Beard Foundation Award winners]]

[[File:Lamberg Ferenc 1791 1848.jpg|thumb|right|Count Franz Philipp von Lamberg
([[Lithography]] of [[Josef Kriehuber]]).]] '''Count Franz Philipp von Lamberg''' ({{lang-hu|Lamberg Ferenc Fülöp}}, November 30, 1791 - September 28, 1848) [[Austria]]n soldier and statesman, was born in [[Mór]] ''(Moor),'' [[Hungary]]. He held the military rank of ''Feldmarschallleutnant''. He entered the third [[Uhlan]] regiment in 1810. He served in the [[War of the Sixth Coalition]] (1813–1814). In 1834 he was promoted to the rank of major. After 32 years of military service, in 1842 he was assigned the rank of ''Feldmarschallleutnant''. In 1848, the circumstance that, as a member of the upper eschelons of the Hungarian nobility, he had been entrusted with Hungarian relations with Austria brought him the difficult, but also distinguished, assignment as imperial commissioner charged with bringing about a peaceful adjustment between the emperor and the people. But before his arrival in [[Budapest|Pest]], [[Lajos Kossuth|Kossuth]] had incited the legislature to forbid his taking office as [[palatine]] of Hungary, and the army was instructed not to obey him. His assignment was without ministerial countersign. After his arrival in Pest, and a short and fruitless discussion with [[Johann Hrabowsky|General Hrabowsky]], he took a cab to a fortification. While crossing the Danube on the pontoon bridge, a mob which had been advised of his arrival fell upon the cab, murdered Lamberg, mutilated the body, and triumphantly carried it, impaled on [[scythe]]s, to the disabled soldiers' home. Lamberg's death marked a turning point in the [[Hungarian Revolution of 1848]], as the Imperial Court in Vienna decided to dissolve the Hungarian Parliament and send in the troops of [[Josip Jelačić]] into Hungary. ==Family and children== With Countess Caroline Hoyos, he had at least two children: * a son, father of Countess Ladislaja von Lamberg; * Countess Theresia von Lamberg, who married [[Franz, Count of Meran]], and had issue. {{clear}} == References == [[File:Mór - Palace.jpg|thumb|right|Lamberg Castle in [[Mór]].]] * {{de-ADB|17|537|537|Lamberg, Franz Philipp Graf von|Adolf Schinzl|ADB:Lamberg, Franz Graf von (österreichischer Feldmarschall)}} * {{NDB|13|429|430|Lamberg, Franz Graf von|Peter Broucek}} * [[Carl Schurz]], ''Lebenserinnerungen bis zum Jahre 1852'', Berlin: [[Georg Reimer]], 1906 and 1911. {{De icon}} Schurz records the death of Lamberg (he spells in “Lemberg”) on pp. 156–157 (Chapter 5). {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lamberg, Franz Philipp, Count von}} [[Category:Austro-Hungarian people]] [[Category:Austrian soldiers]] [[Category:People of the Revolutions of 1848]] [[Category:Lamberg|Franz Philipp]] [[Category:Hungarian nobility]] [[Category:Hungarian people of Austrian descent]] [[Category:Austrian people of Hungarian descent]] [[Category:People from Mór]] [[Category:1791 births]] [[Category:1848 deaths]] {{Hungary-noble-stub}} {{Austria-noble-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox award | name = ECHO | image = Echo Award.jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = Logo | description = Outstanding achievements in the [[music industry]] | presenter = {{Interlanguage link multi|Deutsche Phono-Akademie|de}} | country = Germany | network = [[Das Erste]] (2009–2016) [[VOX (TV channel)|VOX]] (2017-2018) | year = {{start date and age|1992|5|18|df=yes}} | year2 = {{end date|2018|4|12|df=yes}} | website = {{url|echopop.de}} }} '''Echo''' (stylised as '''ECHO''', {{IPA-de|ˈɛço}}) was an accolade by the {{Interlanguage link multi|Deutsche Phono-Akademie|de}}, an association of recording companies of Germany to recognize outstanding achievement in the [[music industry]]. The first ECHO Awards ceremony was held in 1992, and it was set up to honor musical accomplishments by performers for the year 1991, succeeding the [[Deutscher Schallplattenpreis]], which was awarded since 1963. Each year's winner was determined by the previous year's sales. In April 2018, following controversy regarding that year's ceremony, the [[Bundesverband Musikindustrie]] announced the end of the award.<ref>{{cite web|title=Der Echo wird abgeschafft|work=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|faz.net]]|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/der-echo-wird-abgeschafft-15559595.html|accessdate=25 April 2015|date=25 April 2018}} {{de icon}}</ref><ref name="Billboard End">{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8379865/germany-cancels-echo-awards-top-music-prize-anti-semitic-lyrics|title=Germany to Discontinue ECHO Awards, the Country's Top Music Prize, After Anti-Semitic Lyric Backlash|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-04-25}}</ref>
==History== First held with 370 people in the [[Flora und Botanischer Garten Köln|Flora]], [[Cologne]]<ref name=BZ>{{cite web | title =Alles über den Echo | work=[[B.Z. (newspaper)|BZ]] | publisher =Axel Springer | date =7 March 2004 | url =http://www.bz-berlin.de/archiv/alles-ueber-den-echo-article99509.html | accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> in 1992,<ref>{{Cite news | last =Spahr | first =Wolfgang | title =German Stars Honored As Echoes Debut | newspaper =[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]| page =10 | publisher = | date =30 May 1992 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=jg8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA10 | accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> the award ceremony in Frankfurt was televised and the classical awards were moved to a separate event, [[Echo Klassik]], in Cologne in 1994.<ref>{{Cite news | last =Pride | first =Dominic | title =Dance Music (And A Punk Jester) Captivate Echo Awards Ceremony | newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]| page =58 | publisher = | date =26 March 1994 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=NQgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA58 | accessdate =22 June 2010}}</ref> Until 1995, only invited guests could attend the ceremony.<ref name=bisschen>{{cite web | title =Ein bisschen Echo, oder was? |work=[[Der Spiegel]]| publisher =Spiegel Gruppe | date =9 March 2000 | url =http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/musik/0,1518,68398,00.html |accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> It was held in Munich,<ref name=BZ /> and in 2001, the venue was moved from Hamburg to Berlin<ref>{{Cite news | last =Masson | first =Gordon | title =This Year's Model: New Town, New Venue, New Media Partners|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|page=48| publisher = | date =21 April 2001 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=nRQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52 |accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> because of subsidies of up to 20 million euros, although a return in 2004 was considered.<ref>{{cite web | last =Schirg | first =Oliver |author2=Hornung, Klaus | title =Subventions-Geschenke: Echo bleibt doch in Berlin |work=[[Die Welt]]| publisher =Axel Springer | date =23 May 2003 | url =https://www.welt.de/print-welt/article236504/Subventions_Geschenke_Echo_bleibt_doch_in_Berlin.html|accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> In 2009, the venue in Berlin was moved to [[O2 World (Berlin)|O2 World]].<ref>{{cite web | title =EMI artists provide the evening's highlight performances as Germany's ECHO awards shine with a new venue and a first ever live primetime broadcast | work =Music | publisher =EMI Group | date =23 February 2009 | url =http://www.emimusic.com/news/2009/emi-artists-provide-the-evenings-highlight-performances-as-germanys-echo-awards-shine-with-a-new-venue-and-a-first-ever-live-primetime-broadcast/ | accessdate =22 June 2010 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20110606013709/http://www.emimusic.com/news/2009/emi-artists-provide-the-evenings-highlight-performances-as-germanys-echo-awards-shine-with-a-new-venue-and-a-first-ever-live-primetime-broadcast/ | archivedate =6 June 2011 | df =dmy-all }}</ref>
==Trophy== The trophy was designed by Oliver Renelt when he was a student at the [[Hochschule für bildende Künste Hamburg]]. It is stainless steel, and is {{convert|40|cm|in}} tall and weighs {{convert|2|kg|lb}}.<ref name=BZ /> It depicts half a disc with notes flowing into it from a globe, and the design was the winner of a competition held for that purpose.<ref name=bisschen />
== Controversy == The Echo Award was heavily criticized worldwide when [[Farid Bang]] and [[Kollegah]] received the award for best hip hop/urban album in April 2018. The nominated album, ''[[Jung, brutal, gutaussehend 3|Jung, Brutal, Gutaussehend 3]]'' (English: "Young, brutal, handsome 3"), contains the track "0815", in which the artists refer to their muscles as being more defined than those of [[Auschwitz]] inmates. The duo was even allowed to perform this track during the ceremony, despite heavy protests weeks before the award show.
[[Campino (singer)|Campino]], singer of German punk band [[Die Toten Hosen]], was the first one to criticize the committee's decision during the ceremony.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/german-music-business-slammed-anti-semitic-lyric-echo-awards-kollegah-farid-bang-1202758207/|title=German Music Business Slammed Over Anti-Semitic Lyric Controversy at Echo Awards|last=Aswad|first=Jem|date=2018-04-19|work=Variety|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref> His remarks received a standing ovation from the audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/rappers-kollegah-farid-bang-stir-controversy-at-germanys-biggest-music-awards/a-43367267|title=Rappers Kollegah, Farid Bang stir controversy at Germany's biggest music awards {{!}} DW {{!}} 12.04.2018|last=|first=|website=[[Deutsche Welle|dw.com]]|language=en|access-date=2018-04-21}}</ref> Several artists later returned their Echo awards in protest, such as [[Marius Müller-Westernhagen]], who returned all of his seven Echo awards received over the years. Other artists returning their awards were German conductors [[Christian Thielemann]] and [[Enoch zu Guttenberg]], Russian-German pianist [[Igor Levit]], record producer [[Klaus Voormann]], and the Notos Quartett.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/8350353/germany-echo-awards-kollegah-farid-bang-lyrics-controversy|title=Germany's ECHO Awards Under Intense Scrutiny After Allowing Rap Duo With Anti-Semitic Lyrics to Win, Perform|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-04-21}}</ref>
However, criticism did not only come from artists and the German press. Several businesses joined in, with [[Tom Enders]], CEO of [[Airbus]], being one of the most recent high-profile commentators, saying that this would hurt "Germany’s international reputation". He also asked if "antisemitism [was] becoming acceptable in Germany" again.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/music/news/german-music-business-slammed-anti-semitic-lyric-echo-awards-kollegah-farid-bang-1202758207/|title=German Music Business Slammed Over Anti-Semitic Lyric Controversy at Echo Awards|last=Aswad|first=Jem|date=2018-04-19|work=Variety|access-date=2018-04-21|language=en-US}}</ref>
As a consequence, the Echo Award was discontinued.<ref name="Billboard End"/>

==Echo Awards== The [[Kastelruther Spatzen]] have won 13 Echo Awards in the category [[Volksmusik]] which is more than any other artist; the awards were in 1993, 1996–2003, 2006–2010.

===Honorary Award=== *1991 [[Udo Lindenberg]] *1992 [[Reinhard Mey]] *1993 [[Udo Jürgens]] *1994 [[James Last]] *1996 [[Klaus Doldinger]] *1997 [[Frank Farian]] *1998 [[Comedian Harmonists]] *1999 [[Falco (musician)|Falco]] *2000 [[Hildegard Knef]] *2001 [[Fritz Rau]] *2002 [[Caterina Valente]] *2003 [[Can (band)|Can]] *2004 [[Howard Carpendale]] *2005 [[Michael Kunze]] *2006 [[Peter Kraus]] *2007 [[Ralph Siegel]] *2008 [[Rolf Zuckowski]] *2009 [[Scorpions (band)|Scorpions]] *2010 [[Peter Maffay]] *2011 [[Annette Humpe]] *2012 [[Wolfgang Niedecken]] *2013 [[Hannes Wader]]<ref name=EchoArchiv/> *2014 [[Yello]]<ref name="2014 Echo Winners"/> *2015 [[Nana Mouskouri]]<ref name="Echo 2015"/> *2016 [[Puhdys]] *2017 [[Marius Müller-Westernhagen]]
==ECHO KLASSIK== {{main|Echo Klassik}} Following its first edition as a separate event in Cologne in 1994, the ECHO KLASSIK has been held in the [[Semperoper]] in [[Dresden]] in 1996 and 2009,<ref>{{cite web | title =ECHO Klassik im Überblick | publisher =Semperoper | url =http://www.semperoper.de/fileadmin/home/alle/PDFs/semper/semper_0910_1.pdf | format = PDF |accessdate=22 June 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> in [[Dortmund]] in 2003,<ref>{{cite web | title =Preisträger des Echo Klassik stehen fest | work =KIZ | publisher =NMZ | date =26 August 2003 | url =http://www.nmz.de/kiz/nachrichten/preistraeger-des-echo-klassik-stehen-fest|accessdate=22 June 2010}}</ref> in [[Gasteig]] in [[Munich]] from 2004 to 2008 and in 2014.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.echoklassik.de/en/klassik-hintergrund/|title=ECHO Klassik {{!}} Background|last=Musikindustrie|first=Bundesverband|website=www.echoklassik.de|language=en|access-date=2017-11-24}}</ref> In 2010 it was held in [[Essen]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Echo Klassik bringt Melodien für Millionen|work=[[Westdeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung]]|date=17 October 2010|url=https://www.derwesten.de/kultur/Echo-Klassik-bringt-Melodien-fuer-Millionen-id3842377.html|accessdate=9 April 2011|author=Lars von der Gönna|language=German}}</ref> From 2011 until 2016 the award show was held in [[Berlin|Berlin's]] [[Konzerthaus Berlin|Konzerthaus]] - only shortly intermitted in 2014.<ref name=":0" /> In 2017, the ECHO KLASSIK took place in [[Hamburg]]'s newly opened [[Elbphilharmonie]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.echoklassik.de/en/klassik-details/controller/News/action/detail/news/thomas-gottschalk-to-host-the-echo-klassik-2017-in-hamburgs-elbphilharmonie-concert-hall-submi/|title=Thomas Gottschalk to host the ECHO KLASSIK 2017 in Hamburg’s Elbphilharmonie Concert Hall // Submission period starts today|last=Musikindustrie|first=Bundesverband|date=20 February 2017|work=|accessdate=2017-11-24|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
==ECHO JAZZ== {{main|ECHO Jazz}} Since 2010, the ECHO JAZZ awards have been given in thirty categories, including ensemble of the year, male and female singer of the year, record label, and lifetime achievement. In 2012 the criteria for entry included album release date and "two outstanding reviews from music journalists." Conductor [[Claus Ogermann]] was given the ECHO Jazz Lifetime Achievement Award in 2012.<ref name="Announced">{{cite web|last1=Spahr|first1=Wolfgang|title=Germany's ECHO Jazz Award Winners Announced|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/global/1097873/germanys-echo-jazz-award-winners-announced|website=Billboard|accessdate=27 September 2016|date=18 April 2012}}</ref> Awards are decided by a twelve-member jury based on critical and commercial appeal.<ref name="Echo">{{cite web|title=ECHO Jazz 2016: Hamburg|url=https://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http://www.echojazz.de/jazz-detailansicht/controller/News/action/detail/news/der-echo-jazz-verzaubert-hamburg/&usg=ALkJrhjIPGEUtlhFHhtwZHVofUav_dSuPQ|website=Echo Jazz (www.echojazz.de/jazz-startseite)|accessdate=27 September 2016|date=26 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="Hot Hamburg">{{cite web|title=Hamburg's hot jazz scene - ECHO Jazz 2016 award to be held soon|url=http://www.hamburg-news.hamburg/en/cluster/conventions-events/hamburgs-hot-jazz-scene-echo-jazz-2016-award-be-he/|website=Hamburg News|accessdate=27 September 2016|date=23 May 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use British English|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | name ='''Edward Dudley Metcalfe''' | office = [[Equerry]] to the [[Duke of Windsor]] | term_start = 1939 | term_end = 1943 | birth_date = {{birth date|1887|1|16|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|11|18|1887|1|16|df=yes}} | death_place = | image = | caption = | nickname = Fruity | education = [[Trinity College, Dublin]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Lady Alexandra Curzon]]
|1925|1955|reason=div}} | children = 3 | allegiance = {{UK}} | branch = [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]]
[[Royal Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1907–27 (Army)
1940–42 (RAF) | rank = [[Major]] (Army)
[[Flying officer]] (RAF) | commands = | unit = | battles = [[World War I|First World War]] | awards = [[Military Cross|MC]]
[[Mentioned in despatches|Despatches]]
[[Royal Victoria Order|MVO]] | laterwork = Equerry to King Edward VIII }} '''Edward Dudley Metcalfe''' [[Royal Victoria Order|MVO]] [[Military Cross|MC]] (16 January 1887 – 18 November 1957), known as '''Fruity Metcalfe''', was an officer in the [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]] and a close friend and [[equerry]] of the Prince of Wales, later [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|King Edward VIII]] and [[Duke of Windsor]]. ==Early life== Metcalfe was born on 16 January 1887. He was educated privately and at [[Trinity College, Dublin]].Courcy, Anne de (2002) "''The Viceroy's Daughters: the Lives of the Curzon Sisters''", W. Morrow, New York, amazon.co.uk, paperback. Retrieved 23 February 2007 ==Career== He was commissioned on to the Unattached list for Auxiliary Forces (University Candidate) on 27 May 1907. He transferred to the Unattached List, Indian Army on 15 August 1908 but to have seniority from 17 August 1907. He spent a year attached to the 1st battalion [[Connaught Rangers]] in India from 8 November 1908 until, on 8 November 1909, being accepted into the [[British Indian Army|Indian Army]] and joining 3rd [[Skinner's Horse]].Indian Army List October 1909 He was promoted [[lieutenant]] on 17 November 1909.Indian Army List April 1912 He attended the 1911 [[Delhi Durbar]] with his regiment, and in 1912 attended the Cavalry School at [[Sagar, Madhya Pradesh|Saugor]].Indian Army List April 1912 On 12 August 1914 he was appointed Adjutant of the Governor's Body Guard, Bombay.Indian Army List January 1915 He did not hold this position for long as his regiment was mobilised and went to France late in 1914. He was promoted temporary captain 1 September 1915. He served there before being sent back to India in June 1916, from where he volunteered to served with the 7th Meerut Cavalry headquarters which went to Mesopotamia. He was promoted captain 17 August 1916; however this was later antedated to 1 September 1915.{{cite news |url=http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30011/pages/3341 |title=Rank of Captain to be antedated to 1st September, 1915, but without pay or allowances |work=''[[London Gazette]]'' |date=6 April 1917 |accessdate=2012-11-06}} He was [[mentioned in dispatches]], reported in the ''London Gazette'' on 15 August 1917, and ten days later come notice that he had been awarded the [[Military Cross]] for distinguished service in [[Mesopotamia]].''London Gazette'', 25 August 1917 [[File:Edward VIII with his staff wearing Happi 1922.jpg|thumb|350px|Pictured in local costume in Japan in 1922 (L-R): Metcalfe, [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Edward, Prince of Wales]]. and [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Louis Mountbatten]]]] In 1918 Metcalfe was attached to the Signal Service, where he remained until January 1920, when he was attached to the 27th Light Cavalry.Indian Army List, January 1920 By early 1921 he was back serving with the 3rd Skinner's Horse.Indian Army List, July 1921 ===Service with the Prince of Wales=== By July 1921, he was serving with the Indian State Forces of Indore. Metcalfe first met the future Edward VIII when, as Prince of Wales, he was touring India in 1922. Edward was impressed with Metcalfe's knowledge of horses and made him a member of his personal staff, appointing him an aide de camp and subsequently accompanying the prince on his tour of Japan.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,723219,00.html |title=Milestones: Jun. 8, 1925 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=8 June 1925 |accessdate=2007-04-08}} In July 1922, in the wake of the prince's tour, he was appointed a Member of the Royal Victorian Order, 4th class,''London Gazette'', 11 July 1922 and in August 1922 was appointed as temporary [[equerry]] to the Prince of Wales.Ziegler Philip (2004) "''Metcalfe, Edward Dudley''", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Retrieved 24 March 2007 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/101071695/ Oxford Dictionary of National Biography] Metcalfe was provisionally promoted to the rank of [[major]] on 17 August 1922.''London Gazette'' 16 November 1923. He was appointed an Extra [[Aide de camp]] to His Excellency the Commander-in-Chief in India on 4 September 1926 and retired from the Indian Army on 6 September 1927. After the king abdicated on 11 December 1936 and became the [[Duke of Windsor]], Metcalfe was best man at his wedding in France to [[Wallis Simpson]] on 3 June 1937. He was his [[equerry]] from 1939 in Paris and Antibes until the German invasion of France in 1940 prompted the Windsors' evacuation and the Duke's appointment to govern the Bahamas.{{cite book|last=Donaldson|first=Frances|title=Edward VIII|year=1976|publisher=Futura Publications|location=London|isbn=0860077357|edition=1st Omega}} Donaldson quotes extensively from Metcalfe's letters written home to his wife Baba in England. ===Later career=== On 10 August 1940, Metcalfe was commissioned as a [[pilot officer]] into the Administrative and Special Duties Branch of the [[Royal Air Force]]. He was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 10 August 1941. He was posted to Cairo in November 1941, returning to Britain at the end of September 1942, but resigned his commission on 17 November 1942. With his wife he attended meetings of the [[Oswald Mosley]] organization the [[January Club]]{{cite book |title=Feminine fascism: women in Britain's fascist movement |last=Gottlieb |first=Julie V. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2003 |publisher=I.B.Tauris, |location=London |isbn=1-86064-918-1 |page=322 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4z6yVqP1NHYC |accessdate=31 January 2011}} and in May 1934 a dinner at [[London]]'s [[Savoy Hotel]] of the British Fascist Blackshirts,{{cite book |title=The Duchess of Windsor: the secret life |last=Higham |first=Charles |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1989 |publisher=Charter Books |location= |isbn=1-55773-227-2 |page=106 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fanBQgAACAAJ |accessdate=31 January 2011}} of which he was a member.{{cite book |title=Hidden Agenda: How the Duke of Windsor Betrayed the Allies |last=Allen |first=Martin |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2002 |publisher=M. Evans and Co. |location=New York |isbn=0-333-90181-9 |page=70 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ViMqAAAAYAAJ |accessdate=31 January 2011}} ==Personal life== In 1925, Metcalfe married [[Lady Alexandra Curzon|Alexandra Naldera Curzon]] ("''Baba''") (1904–1995),Tompsett Brian C. (2005) [http://www3.dcs.hull.ac.uk/cgi-bin/gedlkup/n=royal?royal57972 Royal Genealogical Data Index to Royal Genealogical Data]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved 17 March 2007 18 years younger than him, and the third daughter of [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston#First marriage .281895.E2.80.931906.29|George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston]] and [[Viceroy of India]], and Lord Curzon's first wife, the American mercantile heiress [[Mary Curzon, Baroness Curzon of Kedleston|Mary Victoria Leiter]]. They had a son, David Metcalfe, and twin daughters Davina and Linda. They divorced in 1955. Metcalfe lived at South Hartfield House, [[Coleman's Hatch]], in the [[Ashdown Forest]], Sussex, about 40 miles south of [[London]].{{cite news |first= |last= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,761962,00.html?iid=chix-sphere |title=Good Old Duke |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=25 September 1939 |accessdate=2007-04-04 }} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Metcalfe}} [[Category:British Indian Army officers]] [[Category:Royal Air Force officers]] [[Category:People from Dublin (city)]] [[Category:1887 births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Dublin]] [[Category:Equerries]] [[Category:Courtiers]]
