revision.comment: Disambiguated: [[Bonneville]] → [[Bonneville, Haute-Savoie]]
removed [[Category:Tiananmen Square protesters of 1989]]; added [[Category:1989 Tiananmen Square protesters]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{for|the boxer|Liu Gang (boxer)}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Liu Gang |image = |caption = |birth_date ={{birth date and age|1961|1|30|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Liaoyuan]], [[Jilin]], [[People's Republic of China|China]] |term_start = 23 April 1989 |term_end = 23 April 1989 |title = Founder of [[Beijing Students' Autonomous Federation]] |predecessor = ''Position established'' |successor = [[Zhou Yongjun]]
(as Chairperson) |alma_mater = [[University of Science and Technology of China]]
[[Peking University]]
[[Columbia University]]
[[New York University]] |known_for = [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989#1986 student demonstrations|1986 Student Demonstrations]]
[[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square protests]] }} {{Chinese name|[[Liu (surname)|Liu (刘)]]}} {{chinese|s=刘刚|t=劉剛|p=Liú Gāng}} '''Liu Gang''' (born 30 January 1961) is a Chinese [[scientist]] and [[revolutionary]] who founded the [[Beijing Students' Autonomous Federation]]. He was a prominent student leader at the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989]].{{cite web|title=Tiananmen's Most Wanted |url=http://sinosphere.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/06/03/tiananmens-most-wanted/ |author=Andrew Jacobs |date=June 3, 2014|publisher= New York Times|accessdate=June 3, 2014}} Liu holds a M.A. in physics from [[Peking University]] and a M.A. in [[computer science]] from [[Columbia University]]. After his exile to the United States in 1996, Liu studied technology and physics at [[Bell Labs]] in [[New Jersey]]. Liu was employed at [[Morgan Stanley]] as a [[Wall Street]] IT analyst.{{cite web |title=From China's Prisons To Columbia's Computers |url=http://engineering.columbia.edu/web/newsletterarchive/archive/engnews_s98/liu.html |publisher=Columbia University |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612000554/http://engineering.columbia.edu/web/newsletterarchive/archive/engnews_s98/liu.html |archivedate=June 12, 2010|accessdate=July 10, 2016}} == Student activist == As an undergraduate student at [[University of Science and Technology of China]] in [[Hefei]], Liu met [[Fang Lizhi]], a pro-democracy activist.{{cite web |title=Guilt by Association: More Documents from the Chinese Trials. News from Asia Watch. P.2 |url=https://www.hrw.org/campaigns/china/scholars/t15/China0791.PDF |date=July 25, 1991 |publisher= News from Asia Watch |accessdate=July 10, 2016}} Then, at [[Peking University]], Liu organized "Democracy Salons". Wang Dan later held a position there. Liu was a 28-year-old graduate when the 1989 demonstrations began. He organized the [[Beijing Students' Autonomous Federation]] and joined the movement's organizing body. As a result, he was sixth on a list of twenty-one activists whose arrests were ordered by the government. Liu went into hiding as a fugitive, but on 15 June 1989, Liu was arrested and charged with attempted subversion of the [[Communist Party of China]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/world/china-arrests-another-student-leader.html?action=click&module=Search®ion=searchResults&mabReward=relbias%3As&url=http%3A%2F%2Fquery.nytimes.com%2Fsearch%2Fsitesearch%2F%23%2FLIU%2BGANG%2F |title=China Arrests Another Student Leader |author=Nicholas D. Kristof |date=June 3, 2014 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }} In 1991, he was convicted and sentenced to six years imprisonment at [[Qincheng Prison]].{{cite web |title=Democracy Leader on Trial in China |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/24/world/democracy-leader-on-trial-in-china.html |author=Sheryl WuDunn |date=January 24, 1991 |publisher= New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web |title=China Tries Another Student for Protests |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/07/world/china-tries-another-student-for-protests.html\ |author=Sheryl WuDunn|date=February 7, 1991|publisher= New York Times|accessdate=July 10, 2016}}{{cite web |title=Imprisoned China Pro-Democrats Charge Torture |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/09/01/world/imprisoned-china-pro-democrats-charge-torture.html?action=click&module=Search®ion=searchResults&mabReward=relbias%3As&url=http%3A%2F%2Fquery.nytimes.com%2Fsearch%2Fsitesearch%2F%23%2FLIU%2BGANG%2F |author=Nicholas D. Kristof |date=September 1, 1992 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web |title=A Gentler China: A special report.; 4 Years After Tiananmen, The Hard Line is Cracking |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1993/06/01/world/gentler-china-special-report-4-years-after-tiananmen-hard-line-cracking.html?gwh=2237D3A723BEAC4F49BC8D04C4402AC7&gwt=pay |author=Nicholas D. Kristof |date=June 1, 1993 |publisher= New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web|title=Chinese Government Shows Video Of 4 Prisoners Mentioned by U.S. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/02/world/chinese-government-shows-video-of-4-prisoners-mentioned-by-us.html |publisher= New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web |title=Chinese Said to Detain Dissidents as Parley Nears |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/10/world/chinese-said-to-detain-dissidents-as-parley-nears.html?action=click&module=Search®ion=searchResults&mabReward=relbias%3As&url=http%3A%2F%2Fquery.nytimes.com%2Fsearch%2Fsitesearch%2F%23%2FLIU%2BGANG%2F |date=August 10, 1995 |publisher= New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }} After his release from prison in 1996, Liu continued to advocate for [[human rights in China]] and organized an underground democracy movement. {{cite web |title=Chinese Take Journalists on Guided Tour of Prison |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/06/world/chinese-take-journalists-on-guided-tour-of-prison.html |author=Patrick E. Tyler |date=March 6, 1994 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016}}{{cite web |title=World News Briefs; China Releases Dissident After 6 Years in Prison |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/19/world/world-news-briefs-china-releases-dissident-after-6-years-in-prison.html |date=June 19, 1995 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }} After moving to the United States, Liu continued his studies at Columbia University in New York City. {{cite web |title=A Top Dissident Flees China And Is Admitted to the U.S. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/04/world/a-top-dissident-flees-china-and-is-admitted-to-the-us.html/ |author=Steven Erlanger |date=May 4, 1996 |publisher=New York Times |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110216070927/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/04/world/a-top-dissident-flees-china-and-is-admitted-to-the-us.html |archivedate=February 16, 2011 |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web |title=Chinese Exiles Wonder How Wind Will Blow |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/21/world/chinese-exiles-wonder-how-wind-will-blow.html?gwh=4C58AA6327BC321F009EF33CB7A9FC6C&gwt=pay |author=Richard Bernstein |date=February 21, 1997 |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }}{{cite web |title=Liu Gang |url=http://concernedscientists.org/1997/10/liu-gang/ |date=October 3, 1997 |publisher=Committee of Concerned Scientists |accessdate=July 10, 2016 }} From there, he continued to support the Chinese democracy movement and in 2011, initiated further [[2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests|pro-democracy protests]].{{cite web |title=Torment of Tiananmen |url=https://nypost.com/2011/08/07/torment-of-tiananmen/ |author=Kathianne Boniello |date=August 7, 2011 |publisher=New York Post |accessdate=August 7, 2011}} == Scientific research == === China === In 1982, Liu received a bachelor's degree in modern mechanics from the [[University of Science and Technology of China]]. He was employed by the [[Aviation Industry Corporation of China]] in [[Shenyang]] in the field of [[aerodynamics]]. He worked in partnership with [[Luo Yang (aircraft designer)|Luo Yang]], and was promoted to head of [[aircraft design process|aircraft design]]. Liu's field of research was the theory of [[air resistance]], and he worked on problems of double-sided entry and [[radar]] technology. In 1984, Liu received a master's degree in [[optics]] from the Department of Physics at [[Peking University]] in [[Beijing]]. While there, he was an assistant teacher.{{cite web|title=Introduce of the China’s 21 "Most Wanted" following Tiananmen Square Massacre|url=http://chinadailymail.com/2013/06/13/chinas-21-most-wanted-following-tiananmen-square-massacre/|date=June 13, 2013|publisher=China Daily Mail|accessdate=June 13, 2013}} Liu returned to work at the China Soft Science Research Institute but was also acting assistant director at the University of Science and Technology of China. In 1988, Liu became an assistant and associate researcher at the Wear-Resistant Materials Development Company of the National Ministry of Higher Education & the [[Dalian Institute of Technology]].{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} He was then transferred to research in the Department of Physics at the [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]]. === United States === In 1996, Liu received a master's degree in computer science from Columbia University. He was invited to speak at the [[New York Academy of Sciences]].{{cite web|title=Wang Dan Press Conference Statement |url=http://www.hrichina.org/en/content/2773|date=April 23, 1998|publisher=Human Rights in China|accessdate= July 10, 2016}} Liu gained employment as a member of technical staff (MTS) at the Mathematics of Networks and Systems Research Department at Bell Laboratories in [[Murray Hill, New Jersey|Murray Hill]], New Jersey. There he worked on [[Optical telecommunication]] network design and planning, [[routing]] [[algorithms]], [[optimization]] techniques, and [[economic model]]s and [[strategy]] analysis.{{cite web|title=Introduce of Gang Liu|url=http://cm.bell-labs.com/cm/ms/who/gang/index.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806081009/http://cm.bell-labs.com/cm/ms/who/gang/index.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 6, 2014|publisher=Bell's Lab|accessdate=July 10, 2016 }} Liu's areas of research included: SPIDER, a design tool for fast-restoration in all-optical networks; VPNStar, a system for provisioning multi-service [[VPNs]] with [[Quality of service]] guarantees over [[Internet Protocol]]; in software design, a management system for Lambda Router in all-optical networks; and analysis of [[Internet]] pricing.{{cite web|title=Active Research Projects of Gang Liu|url=http://cm.bell-labs.com/who/gang/proj.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806081005/http://cm.bell-labs.com/who/gang/proj.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2014-08-06|publisher=Bell's Lab}} During his days at Bell Laboratories, Liu introduced the A*Prune (1999, {{ISSN|0743-166X}}) with K. G. Ramakrishnan, to describe a new class of [[Algorithm]]. This opened a new research direction in [[theoretical science]]. He found that A*Prune is comparable to the current best known-approximate algorithms for most randomly generated [[Graph (discrete mathematics)|graphs]]. The algorithm constructs paths, starting at the source and going towards the destination. But, at each iteration, the [[algorithm]] is rid of all paths that are guaranteed to violate the constraints, thereby keeping only those partial paths that have the potential to be turned into feasible paths, from which the [[optimal]] paths are drawn.{{cite web|title=A*Prune: An Algorithm for Finding K Shortest Paths Subject to Multiple Constraints|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/2370289_A*Prune_An_Algorithm_for_Finding_K_Shortest_Paths_Subject_to_Multiple_Constraints|date=August 2001|publisher=Research Gate|accessdate=July 10, 2016}} Liu also proposed a special class of Optical devices called SPIDER (2001, {{ISSN|1089-7089}}); optical routers, dense [[wavelength division multiplexing]] (DWDM) systems, and cross-connects of unprecedented capacities. Liu and his colleagues are developing techniques for efficient and reliable [[Optical telecommunication|optical network]] design, covering decentralized dedicated protection to shared path-based mesh restoration.{{cite web|last1=Davis|first1=R. Drew|last2=Kumar|first2=K.|last3=Liu|first3=Gang|last4=Sanlee|first4=Iraj|title=SPIDER: A Simple and Flexible Tool for Design and Provisioning of Protected Lightpaths in Optical Networks|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/220440646_SPIDER_A_Simple_and_Flexible_Tool_for_Design_and_Provisioning_of_Protected_Lightpaths_in_Optical_Networks|publisher=Research Gate|date=March 2000|accessdate=11 July 2016}} Since 2011, Liu had been involved in a bitter divorce with his former wife, the judge presided the case had declared him mentally unstable, and appointed a custodian guardian to represent him against his wish; among Liu's accusations: his wife was a spy sent by Chinese Communist central committee to monitor him, and his ex-employer Morgan Stanley fired him to appease Chinese government.{{cite web|title=Torment of Tiananmen|url=https://nypost.com/2011/08/07/torment-of-tiananmen/|publisher= New York Post|accessdate=August 7, 2011}} == Articles == * Liu G. [http://article.sapub.org/pdf/10.5923.j.algorithms.20140301.01.pdf ''T-Forward Method: a Closed-Form Solution and Strongly Polynomial Time Approach for Convex Nonlinear Programming.''] Algorithms Research, Elmhurst, New York 2014 3(1):1-25. * Liu G. [http://article.sapub.org/pdf/10.5923.j.economics.20140402.01.pdf ''A Mathematic Model for Supply-Demand Equilibrium and the Optimal Solution for Labor Assignment''] American Journal of Economics, Elmhurst, New York, 2014 4(2):83-98 doi 10.5923/j.economics.20140402.01 * Liu G. et al. [http://cm.bell-labs.com/who/drew/pub/bltj-spider.pdf ''SPIDER: A Simple and Flexible Tool for Design and Provisioning of Protected Lightpaths in Optical Networks'']{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Bell Laboratories Technical Memorandum, Murray Hill, New Jersey, 2001. * Liu G. and Ramakrishnan K. G. ''A*Prune: an Algorithm for Finding K Shortest Paths Subject to Multiple Constraints.'' Bell Laboratories Technical Memorandum 10009626-000302-04TM, Murray Hill, New Jersey, 1999. {{citeseerx|10.1.1.20.8011}} * Liu G. et al. ''Algorithms for DWDM Mesh Network Design: Routing and Wavelength Assignment for Dedicated Protection, Ring Auto-Recovery and Optical Cross-Connect Restoration in Core Optical Networks.'' Bell Laboratories Technical Memorandum 10009626-000126-01TM, Murray Hill, New Jersey, 1999. * Liu G. and Stern T. E. ''An Algorithm for Optimal Routing and Wavelength Assignment on a Bi-directional Ring'' Bell Laboratories Technical Memorandum BL0112120-990610-10TM, Murray Hill, New Jersey, 1999. ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==External links== * [http://www.quatratic.com/ Quatratic.com] — A website solver for Convex Nonlinear Programming {{optimization algorithms}} {{Fall of Communism}} {{1989 Tiananmen protests}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Liu, Gang}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chinese mathematicians]] [[Category:Chinese revolutionaries]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:Number theorists]] [[Category:Theoretical physicists]] [[Category:Scientists at Bell Labs]] [[Category:Morgan Stanley employees]] [[Category:Citigroup employees]] [[Category:People's Republic of China emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:University of Science and Technology of China alumni]] [[Category:Peking University alumni]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Chinese political writers]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the People's Republic of China]] [[Category:1989 Tiananmen Square protesters]] [[Category:Chinese dissidents]] [[Category:Chinese human rights activists]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Louisa Nécib | image = Louisa Nécib 2015.jpg | image_size = 260 | caption = Nécib with [[France women's national football team|France]] in 2015 | fullname = Louisa Nécib Cadamuro | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|1|23|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Marseille]], France | height = {{height|m=1.68}}<ref>[http://www.fifadata.com/document/FWWC/2015/pdf/FWWC_2015_SquadLists.pdf 2015 World Cup]</ref> | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = 2000–2002 | youthclubs1 = US Marseille | youthyears2 = 2002–2004 | youthclubs2 = Celtic de Marseille | years1 = 2004–2006 | clubs1 = [[CNFE Clairefontaine]] | caps1 = 38 | goals1 = 9 | years2 = 2006–2007 | clubs2 = [[Montpellier HSC (Ladies)|Montpellier]] | caps2 = 20 | goals2 = 11 | years3 = 2007–2016 | clubs3 = [[Olympique Lyonnais (Ladies)|Lyon]] | caps3 = 173 <!-- LEAGUE APPEARANCES & GOALS ONLY--> | goals3 = 64 | totalcaps = 231 | totalgoals = 84 | nationalyears1 = 2003 | nationalteam1 = [[France women's national under-17 football team|France U17]] | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | nationalyears2 = 2004–2005 | nationalteam2 = [[France women's national under-19 football team|France U19]] | nationalcaps2 = | nationalgoals2 = | nationalyears3 = 2006 | nationalteam3 = [[France women's national under-20 football team|France U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 6 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | nationalyears4 = 2005–2016 | nationalteam4 = [[France women's national football team|France]] | nationalcaps4 = 145 | nationalgoals4 = 36 | club-update = 03:13, 14 August 2016 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 03:13, 14 August 2016 (UTC) }}
'''Louisa Nécib Cadamuro''' ({{IPA-fr|luiza neˈsib}}; born 23 January 1987) is a retired [[List of France women's international footballers|French women's international footballer]]. She spent the majority of her career at [[Olympique Lyonnais (ladies)|Lyon]], amassing eighteen titles with the French club over a nine-year span. She played as a [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|central attacking midfielder]] and is described as a "gifted [[playmaker]]" who "possesses superb technique".<ref name="necib_fifa">{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=108/edition=10292/news/newsid=105580.html | title = Necib following in famous footsteps | date = 26 August 2006 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 11 June 2011 }}</ref> Nécib is also known for her "elegant possession, sublime passing skills, and cultured touch on the ball".<ref name="necib_cbc">{{cite news | url = http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/fifawomensworldcup2011/blog/2011/07/more-to-come-from-louisa-necib.html | title = More to come from Louisa Necib | date = 14 July 2011 | work = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
She has been labeled by the French media as "the female [[Zinedine Zidane|Zidane]]" – like Zinedine Zidane, she has Algerian ancestry, grew up in Marseille and possesses immense skill, especially as a playmaker with an eye for goal. As such, she has been nicknamed "Ziza", a variant of Zidane's "Zizou".<ref name="necib_fifa"/><ref name="necib_marseille">{{cite news | url = http://www.lefigaro.fr/sport/2009/03/07/02001-20090307ARTFIG00224-louisa-necib-gracieuse-en-talons-et-en-crampons-.php | title = Louisa Necib, gracieuse en talons et en crampons | date = 16 March 2009 | work = Le Figaro | accessdate = 11 June 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lesdessousdusport.fr/louisa-necib-la-zidane-du-foot-feminin-3426 | title = Louisa Necib, la "Zidane" du foot féminin | date = 16 February 2009 | work = Les dessous du sport | accessdate = 11 June 2011 | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120909014539/http://www.lesdessousdusport.fr/louisa-necib-la-zidane-du-foot-feminin-3426 | archivedate = 9 September 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="necib_20minutes">{{cite news | url = http://www.20minutes.fr/article/750209/louisa-necib-itineraire-enfant-balle | title = Louisa Necib, itinéraire d'une enfant de la balle | date = 29 June 2011 | work = 20 Minutes | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In an interview with FIFA.com just before the [[2012 Olympics soccer|2012 Olympics]], she alluded to the comparison, saying, "Zidane is a role model for me. He was always the player that I most enjoyed watching. The comparison was made frequently when I was starting out, and now, as the years pass, it happens less and less often. But I wouldn't say I’m tired of it." <ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensolympic/news/newsid=1578093 | title = Nécib: Zidane is my role model | date = 1 February 2012 | work = FIFA.com | accessdate = 28 August 2014 }}</ref> She often attempts to downplay the comparison, though, stating "Being compared to Zidane is really nice, but I don’t think it can harm me because I’ve been hearing it since I was very young. It always makes me proud, but as I always say, I don’t think you can compare anyone to him. He's unique".<ref name="necib_ray"/> While training at the Clairefontaine academy in 2004, Nécib met Zidane, who was at the training center in preparation for [[2006 FIFA World Cup qualification|qualifying for the 2006 World Cup]] (the finals would eventually be his last act as a professional). The two players exchanged shirts, and the shirt Nécib acquired from Zidane is currently in the possession of her father.<ref name="necib_federation"/>
Nécib began her football career playing for local youth clubs in her hometown of [[Marseille]], such as Union Sportive Marseille and Celtic de Marseille. With the latter club, she made her senior team debut in 2003 and, in the following season, helped the club win the Division 3 Féminine. In 2004, Nécib was selected to attend [[CNFE Clairefontaine]], the women's section of the Clairefontaine academy. She spent two years at the training center, and in 2006, departed for [[Montpellier HSC (Ladies)|Montpellier]] of the [[Division 1 Féminine]]. In her only season with Montpellier, Nécib helped the team win the 2006–07 edition of the [[Challenge de France]]. After departing Montpellier, she joined [[Olympique Lyonnais (Ladies)|Lyon]]. Since joining the club, Nécib has won a slew of trophies, which include four league titles, one Challenge de France, and one [[UEFA Women's Champions League]] title. For her performances during the [[2008–09 Division 1 Féminine|2008–09 season]], she was named the [[National Union of Professional Footballers]] (UNFP) [[Trophées UNFP du football#Player of the Year 3|Female Player of the Year]].
Nécib is a former French women's youth international having represented her nation at all levels for which she was eligible. At under-19 level, she played on the teams that reached the [[2004 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship|2004]] and [[2005 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship|2005]] editions of the [[UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship]]. With the under-20 team, Nécib played at the [[2006 FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship]] scoring a goal in the group stage against [[Argentina women's national football team|Argentina]] as France reached the quarter-finals. Prior to playing in the U-20 Women's World Cup, Nécib made her senior international debut in February 2005 in a friendly match against [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]]. Two years later in March 2007, Nécib scored her first senior international goal in a [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009 qualifying]] victory over [[Greece women's national football team|Greece]]. She has participated in five major international tournaments for her country; the [[UEFA Women's Euro 2005|2005]] and [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009|2009]] editions of [[UEFA Women's Euro]] and the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|2011]] and [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]] and the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]. In the latter competition, Nécib acted as the [[playmaker]] and contributed to the team that finished in fourth place.
==Personal life== Nécib was born on 23 January 1987 in the city of [[Marseille]] to parents of [[Algeria]]n origin. Her father had emigrated to France from [[Biskra]], while her mother had come from [[Oran]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.lebuteur.com/entretien/actualites/louisa-necib-la-zidanette-de-france | title = Louisa Necib la Zidanette de France | date = | work = Le Buteur | accessdate = 11 June 2011 | language = French | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120321094324/http://www.lebuteur.com/entretien/actualites/louisa-necib-la-zidanette-de-france | archivedate = 21 March 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> Nécib was raised in Busserine, a quartier located in the northern suburbs of the [[14th arrondissement of Marseille]] and has a brother and sister.<ref name="necib_marseille"/> After signing with Lyon, Nécib enrolled at the [[Claude Bernard University Lyon 1|Université Lyon 1]] with hopes of completing her undergraduate studies in ''Sciences et techniques des activités physiques et sportives'' (STAP) ({{lang-en|Science and Technology of Sport and Physical Activity}}).<ref name="necib_marseille"/> She developed an interest in [[Association football|football]] at a young age, prior to which she trained in [[gymnastics]].<ref name="necib_laprovence2">{{cite news | url = http://www.laprovence.com/article/tous-sports-188 | title = Coupe du monde: Louisa Necib, la "Zidane du foot féminin"? | date = 13 July 2011 | work = La Provence | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> She, initially, did not look at the future prospects of women's football and played mainly for recreation with males stating "I'd always played with the boys in my neighborhood" and "I didn't plan to join a club because, to be honest, I didn't know girls' teams existed. Then, one day I found out there was a club in the 14th arrondissement and I signed up".<ref name="necib_fifa"/>
In June 2016, she married footballer [[Liassine Cadamuro]]-Bentaïba.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Louisa-necib-mon-meilleur-souvenir-c-est-mon-mariage/702981|title=Louisa Necib: "Mon meilleur souvenir, c'est mon mariage"|trans-title=Louisa Necib: "My best memory, my marriage"|work=[[L'Équipe]]|language=French|date=4 July 2016|access-date=6 December 2016}}</ref>
==Club career==
===Early career=== {{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote= "These comparisons do not bother me. To be compared with ''Zizou'' is a pride. But there is no comparison to make. I am myself." |source= <small> Nécib on the comparisons to [[Zinedine Zidane]].<ref name="necib_laprovence2"/></small> }}
Nécib began her career as a youth player for her hometown club Union Sportive de Marseille.<ref name="necib_laprovence1">{{cite news | url = http://www.laprovence.com/article/sports-region/football-louisa-necib-la-star-marseillaise-de-lol | title = Football : Louisa Necib, la star marseillaise de l'OL | date = 7 November 2009 | work = La Provence | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> After spending two years at the club, she signed on with nearby Celtic de Marseille. Nécib spent six months developing in the academy and, in April 2002, she was selected to attend the under-16 female National Cup representing her [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur|region]]. The competition served as a training camp for the Centre National de Formation et d'Entraînement (CNFE) ({{lang-en|National Center for Education and Training}}) located at the [[INF Clairefontaine|Clairefontaine]] academy in [[Clairefontaine-en-Yvelines]]. The initiative to allow women to train at the famous national center came about in the 1990s due to the fact that it had quickly become a high-level training facility for male football players. As a result of allowing female football players to train at the academy, younger women were afforded the same benefits from the facilities offered by Clairefontaine as the men. At the National Cup, Nécib impressed and was given an award by coaches for possessing the best shot of any player.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/presentationfff/actualite/22573.shtml | title = Résultats des tests (groupe A) | date = 16 April 2002 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> After the competition, she returned to Celtic.
At the age of 16, Nécib was promoted to the senior team by coach Yohan Silvy in the latter part of the 2002–03 season.<ref name="necib_laprovence1"/> While at the club, Nécib was teammates with future national teammate [[Caroline Pizzala]]. In the 2003–04 season, Nécib flourished and helped the club reach the Division 3 Féminine league final where they faced the women's team of professional men's club [[Le Mans FC|Le Mans]]. In the tie, Nécib started and played the full match as Celtic cruised to a 4–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/journee.php?id=166&numero=0#fiche_match_9899 | title = Finale D3 2003–2004 – 0e journée | date = 13 June 2004 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> The result promoted the club to the Division 2 Féminine, the second division of French women's football. Nécib's performance that season attracted numerous attention, which resulted in her being nicknamed ''Titou'' as homage to [[Zinedine Zidane]], who is nicknamed ''Zizou''.<ref name="necib_laprovence1"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://surfacemagazine.fr/?p=1585 | title = Louisa Necib: Joueuse de l'Olympique Lyonnais et de l'Équipe de France | date = 10 August 2006 | work = Surface Magazine | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
After three years with Celtic, in July 2004, Nécib was selected to attend the CNFE academy at Clairefontaine.<ref name="necib_marseille"/> She initially struggled to adapt at the center admitting "the first year was really hard because I was so far from my family. I almost gave up".<ref name="necib_fifa"/> However, after developing a rapport with future international teammates [[Sarah Bouhaddi]], [[Élodie Thomis]], [[Laure Boulleau]], [[Jessica Houara]], and the aforementioned Pizzala, Nécib quickly returned to the form that got her selected to the center.<ref name="necib_fifa"/> The CNFE academy is allowed participation in the French women's football league system and, from 2002–2007, fielded a team that participated in the Division 1 Féminine. Nécib spent two seasons with the team and made her league debut on 29 August 2004 against [[Olympique Lyonnais (Ladies)|Lyon]]. In the match, she scored the only goal, a 90th-minute winner, in a 1–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=450 | title = 1ère journée – Lyon-CNFE 0–1 | date = 29 August 2004 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib finished the campaign with 20 league appearances and six goals. Four of her six goals came in the final four weeks of the season. On 26 March 2005, she scored a double in a 4–2 defeat to [[FCF Juvisy|Juvisy]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=554 | title = 19e journée – Juvisy-CNFE 4–2 | date = 26 March 2005 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> A week later, she scored the only goal in a win over Olympique Saint-Memmie and, on the final match day of the season, she scored the team's fourth goal in a 5–1 win over Lyon.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=560 | title = 20e journée – CNFE-Saint-Memmie 1–0 | date = 3 April 2005 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=576 | title = 22e journée – CNFE-Lyon 5–1 | date = 8 May 2005 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> CNFE ultimately finished the campaign in 5th-place position. In the following season, Nécib appeared in 18 matches and scored three goals, all of which came in victories.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=367 | title = 10e journée – Saint-Memmie-CNFE 0–5 | date = 27 November 2005 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=392 | title = 14e journée – CNFE-Lyon 1–0 | date = 8 January 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
===Montpellier=== After completing her education and training at Clairefontaine, Nécib returned to the [[Southern France|south of France]] to sign with Division 1 Féminine club [[Montpellier HSC (Ladies)|Montpellier]]. She joined the club alongside former Clairefontaine teammate Thomis and made her debut on 3 September 2006 in a 0–0 league draw with [[Toulouse FC (Ladies)|Toulouse]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7 | title = 1ère journée – Montpellier-Toulouse 0–0 | date = 3 September 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> She scored her first goal for the club two weeks later on 17 September converting a double in a 5–0 away win over USCO Compiègne.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=17 | title = 3e journée – Compiègne-Montpellier 0–5 | date = 17 September 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 8 October, Nécib scored the second goal in a 2–0 victory against [[ASJ Soyaux|Soyaux]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=23 | title = 4e journée – Montpellier-Soyaux 2–1 | date = 8 October 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In November, she scored two goals each in wins over FCF Condé-sur-Noireau and [[FCF Hénin-Beaumont|Hénin-Beaumont]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=38 | title = 7e journée – Condé-Montpellier 0–4 | date = 12 November 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=47 | title = 8e journée – Montpellier-Hénin-Beaumont 8–0 | date = 19 November 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib finished the campaign with 11 league goals, which was third-best on the team behind Thomis and [[Elodie Ramos]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/buteuses.php?id=1 | title = Championnat de France de D1 2006–2007 – Classement des buteuses | date = | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the [[Challenge de France]], the women's domestic cup competition in France, Nécib helped Montpellier reach the final where the team faced Lyon. She played the entire match as Montpellier won 3–0 on penalties.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/coup/challenge/actualite/375994_victoire-de-montpellier | title = Victoire de Montpellier! | date = 12 May 2007 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> The domestic cup title was Nécib's first major honour of her career.
===Lyon=== Following the season, on 22 June 2007, Lyon officials announced that the club had signed both Nécib and Thomis to contracts.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://nocdn.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/news/newsid=554631.html | title = Lyon sign 'Zidane' and 'Henry' | date = 22 June 2007 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 19 June 2011 }}</ref> Nécib was handed the number 14 shirt and made her club debut on 2 September 2007 in the team's opening league match of the campaign; a 4–0 win over [[ESOF Vendée La Roche-sur-Yon|La Roche-sur-Yon]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=1131 | title = 1ère journée – Lyon-La Roche-sur-Yon 4–0 | date = 2 September 2007 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> A week later, she scored her first goal for Lyon converting a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]] in a 2–0 win against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C. (Ladies)|Paris Saint-Germain]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=1140 | title = 2e journée – PSG-Lyon 0–2 | date = 9 September 2007 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib also made her debut in [[UEFA|European competition]] participating in the [[2007–08 UEFA Women's Cup|2007–08 edition]] of the [[UEFA Women's Cup]]. On her debut against the women's team of [[Slovakia|Slovak]] outfit [[FK Slovan Duslo Šaľa|Slovan Duslo Šaľa]] in the group stage, Nécib netted a [[hat trick]] in a 12–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/news/newsid=569515.html | title = Bardolino and Lyon start in style | date = 10 August 2007 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> She ultimately finished the European campaign appearing in ten matches and scoring six goals as Lyon reached the semi-finals where the club was eliminated by [[Sweden|Swedish]] club [[Umeå IK|Umeå]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15158/match=301705/report=rp.html | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120707194639/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15158/match=301705/report=rp.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 7 July 2012 | title = Umeå scrape through to fifth final | date = 6 April 2008 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> While simultaneously performing well in Europe, Nécib remained productive in the league scoring in league wins over Toulouse, Hénin-Beaumont, and Soyaux late in the season.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=1233 | title = 18e journée – Toulouse-Lyon 0–1 | date = 13 April 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=1239 | title = 19e journée – Lyon-Hénin-Beaumont 11–0 | date = 4 May 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=1251 | title = 21e journée – Lyon-Soyaux 6–0 | date = 25 May 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Lyon eventually pulled away from both Juvisy and Montpellier in the league standings to claim its second straight league title and Nécib's first overall.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/champ/femininesD1/actualite/443069_on-ira-pour-gagner | title = On ira pour gagner | date = 23 May 2008 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib later helped Lyon capture its third Challenge de France, which completed the club's [[Double (association football)|league and cup double]] that season. She scored the second goal in a 3–0 win over Paris Saint-Germain in the final match.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=3053 | title = Finale – PSG (D1)–Lyon (D1) 0–3 | date = 3 June 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
[[File:Louisa Nécib.JPG|260px|thumb|left|Nécib participating in a league match against [[AS Montigny-le-Bretonneux|Montigny-le-Bretonneux]] in the [[2009–10 Division 1 Féminine|2009–10 season]].]] During the infancy of the [[2008–09 Division 1 Féminine|2008–09 season]], Nécib was selected to join the new United States-based women's soccer league, [[Women's Professional Soccer]], after her American playing rights were assigned to the [[Washington Freedom]] in the [[2008 WPS International Draft]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.potomacsoccerwire.com/news/460/3869 | title = Freedom make trade, chose foreign player targets | date = 24 September 2008 | work = Potomac Soccer Wire | accessdate = 11 June 2011 }}</ref> Her Lyon teammate [[Sonia Bompastor]] was also assigned to the Freedom. While Bompastor was allowed to negotiate her exit out of the club, Lyon [[chairman]] [[Jean-Michel Aulas]] was able to convince Nécib to remain in France after having previously declared the player off limits.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://fr.sports.yahoo.com/19022009/79/lyon-deux-bleues-en-partance.html?order=ratings | title = Lyon: deux Bleues en partance | date = 3 June 2008 | work = [[Yahoo!]] | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib scored her first league goal of the campaign on 14 September 2008 in a 12–0 home win over Vendenheim.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=3398 | title = 4e journée – Lyon-Vendenheim 12–0 | date = 14 September 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> A month later, she scored a double in an 8–1 victory over Soyaux.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=3414 | title = 7e journée – Soyaux-Lyon 1–8 | date = 26 October 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib repeated her two-goal display on 1 February 2009 in a 5–0 away win over [[En Avant de Guingamp (Ladies)|Stade Briochin]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=3442 | title = 11e journée – Saint-Brieuc-Lyon 0–5 | date = 26 October 2008 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the UEFA Women's Cup, Nécib scored her first two goals of the campaign in an 8–0 home win over Austrian club [[SV Neulengbach|Neulengbach]] in a second qualifying round group stage match.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.futbol24.com/match/2008/10/09/international/UEFA/Womens-Cup/2008-2009/Group-B3/Lyon-%28W%29/vs/Neulengbach%28W%29/ | title = Lyon 8–0 Neulengbach | date = 9 October 2008 | work = Futbol24 | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> On 18 November, she scored the third goal in a 4–1 second leg win over Italian club [[A.S.D. C.F. Bardolino Verona|Bardolino]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15308/match=304276/report=rp.html | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120709022646/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15308/match=304276/report=rp.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 9 July 2012 | title = Lyon complete job to set up Duisburg tie | date = 18 November 2008 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> The 9–1 aggregate scoreline advanced Lyon to the semi-finals for the second consecutive season where Lyon were again eliminated, this time by German team [[FCR 2001 Duisburg]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15309/match=304470/report=rp.html | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120711223231/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/womencup/fixturesresults/round=15309/match=304470/report=rp.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 11 July 2012 | title = Grings goals take Duisburg to final | date = 5 April 2009 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> In the league, Lyon captured its third straight league title, but was unable to defend its Challenge de France title losing to the eventual champions Montpellier in the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/champ/femininesD1/actualite/528941_l-olympique-lyonnais-remporte-le-titre | title = L'Olympique Lyonnais remporte le titre | date = 11 May 2009 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/coup/challenge/actualite/529213_aubert-m-barek,-l-interview-croisee | title = Aubert – M'Barek, l'interview croisée | date = 14 June 2009 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> For her performances during the campaign, Nécib was named the [[National Union of Professional Footballers]] (UNFP) [[Trophées UNFP du football#Player of the Year 3|Female Player of the Year]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.laprovence.com/actu/la-liste-complete-des-trophees-unfp| title = La liste complète des Trophées UNFP | date = 24 March 2009 | work = La Provence | accessdate = 11 June 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
In the [[2009–10 Division 1 Féminine|2009–10 season]], Nécib switched to the [[Squad number (association football)|number 10 shirt]] and, due to participating in [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009]], was limited to two substitute appearances in the team's first three matches of the season.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6249 | title = 2e journée – Lyon-Yzeure 4–0 | date = 4 October 2009 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6254 | title = 3e journée – Lyon-Saint-Etienne 5–0 | date = 10 October 2009 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 9 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In her first start of the campaign against Soyaux, she scored a double in a 5–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6260 | title = 4e journée – Lyon-Soyaux 5–0 | date = 18 October 2009 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the team's first match following the September international break, Nécib scored a goal in the team's 7–1 away win over Toulouse.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6264 | title = 5e journée – Toulouse-Lyon 1–7 | date = 1 November 2009 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In November, while on international duty with France, Nécib suffered an injury and, subsequently, missed five weeks domestically. She returned to the team in the new year in a league match against [[AS Saint-Étienne (Ladies)|Saint-Étienne]]. In the match, she scored a goal in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6321 | title = 13e journée – Saint-Etienne-Lyon 0–4 | date = 7 February 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Nécib finished the campaign scoring two goals in the team's final four league matches as Lyon claimed its fourth consecutive league championship and reached the semi-finals of the Challenge de France.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6351 | title = 18e journée – La Roche-sur-Yon-Lyon 0–5 | date = 24 May 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=6370 | title = 21e journée – Lyon-Saint-Brieuc 5–0 | date = 6 June 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/champ/femininesD1/actualite/533747_4eme-sacre-pour-l-olympique-lyonnais | title = 4ème sacre pour l'Olympique Lyonnais | date = 14 June 2010 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/coup/challenge/actualite/532982_une-finale-paris-sg-montpellier | title = Une finale Paris-SG-Montpellier | date = 25 April 2010 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the re-branded [[UEFA Women's Champions League]], Nécib made eight appearances scoring four goals as Lyon reached [[2010 UEFA Women's Champions League Final|the final]]. In the semi-finals against Umeå, she converted two goals in a 3–2 first leg victory.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://nocdn.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000061/match=2001499/postmatch/report/index.html#lyon+take+upper+hand | title = Late strike leaves Lyon in charge | date = 10 April 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref> The 0–0 draw in the second leg allowed Lyon to advance to the final.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://secure.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000061/match=2001501/postmatch/report/index.html | title = Lively Lyon set up Potsdam final | date = 28 April 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref> In the penultimate match, Lyon faced [[Germany|German]] club [[1. FFC Turbine Potsdam|Turbine Potsdam]]. Nécib played the entire match in regulation time, but was substituted out prior to the start of [[extra time]]. Lyon eventually conceded defeat losing 7–6 on [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalties]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://pl.static.dr.infra.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/season=2010/matches/round=2000062/match=2001503/postmatch/report/index.html#penalties+give+potsdam+title | title = Potsdam hold nerve to claim European crown | date = 20 May 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref>
[[File:20130929 - PSG-Lyon 052.jpg|thumb|right|Nécib with Lyon in 2013]] For the second time in her career at Lyon, in the [[2010–11 Division 1 Féminine|2010–11 season]], Nécib converted double-digit goals scoring 14, which was third-best on the team behind [[Sandrine Brétigny]] and [[Eugénie Le Sommer]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/buteuses.php?id=130 | title = Championnat de France de D1 2010–2011 – Classement des buteuses | date = | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> She opened the campaign by scoring in the team's first league match; a 6–0 win over Toulouse.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7752 | title = 1ère journée – Lyon-Toulouse 6–0 | date = 5 September 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Two weeks later, Nécib scored the second goal in a 3–0 victory against Stade Briochin.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7765 | title = 3e journée – Lyon-Saint-Brieuc 3–0 | date = 26 September 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> After scoring against La Roche-sur-Yon on 7 November 2010, she went scoreless for two months.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7787 | title = 7e journée – La Roche-sur-Yon-Lyon 0–4 | date = 7 November 2010 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 9 January 2011, she scored two goals in a 7–0 home win over Hénin-Beaumont.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7825 | title = 12e journée – Lyon-Hénin-Beaumont 7–0 | date = 9 January 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Two weeks later, Nécib scored another set of goals, this time against Juvisy in a 7–1 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7835 | title = 14e journée – Lyon-Juvisy 7–1 | date = 23 January 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the Challenge de France, she scored in back-to-back rounds against [[AS Montigny-le-Bretonneux|Montigny-le-Bretonneux]] and [[Rodez AF|Rodez]] before playing 53 minutes in a quarter-final defeat on penalties to Juvisy.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=12872 | title = Seizièmes de finale – Lyon (D1)–Montigny (D2) 13–0 | date = 20 February 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=13190 | title = Huitièmes de finale – Lyon (D1)–Rodez (D1) 3–0 | date = 13 March 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=13417 | title = Quarts de finales – Juvisy (D1)–Lyon (D1) 0–0 | date = 3 April 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On the final match day of the season, despite Lyon clinching its fifth straight league title with several matches to spare, Nécib started the match and scored her first league hat trick in an 8–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/match.php?id=7878 | title = 21e journée – Lyon-Saint-Etienne 8–0 | date = 3 April 2011 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/news/newsid%3D1612762.html | title = Lyon take title, Arsenal through, Potsdam lose | date = 27 March 2007 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 9 September 2011 }}</ref> In the [[2010–11 UEFA Women's Champions League|2010–11 edition]] of the Women's Champions League, she scored her only goal of the competition on 4 November 2010 in the first leg of Lyon's Round of 16 tie against [[Russia]]n club [[WFC Rossiyanka|Rossiyanka]]. Nécib netted the final goal in a 6–1 away win.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://int.women.soccerway.com/matches/2010/11/04/europe/uefa-womens-champions-league/rossiyanka-moskovskaya-oblast/olympique-lyonnais-feminin/1044388/ | title = Rossiyanka vs. Olympique Lyon 1 – 6 | work = Soccerway | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref> Despite her limited scoring, Lyon still reached [[2011 UEFA Women's Champions League Final|the final]] where the team faced its nemesis Turbine Potsdam. In the final, Nécib started the match and played 55 minutes before being substituted out. Lyon went on to win the match 2–0 to claim its first-ever European title.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dr.infra.uefa.com/womenschampionsleague/season=2011/matches/round=2000174/match=2007921/postmatch/report/index.html#lyon+take+title+france | title = Classy Lyon take title from Potsdam | date = 26 May 2011 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref>
After the 2011–12 season, Nécib's contract with Lyon expired, which led to speculation that the player would join league rivals Paris Saint-Germain.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.eurosport.fr/football/ligue-1/2011-2012/necib-courtisee-par-le-psg_sto3280563/story.shtml | title = Necib courtisée par le PSG | date = 22 May 2012 | work = [[Eurosport]] | accessdate = 19 July 2012 | language = French}}</ref> However, on 16 July 2012, Nécib re-signed with Lyon after agreeing to a four-year contract with an option for a fifth year.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Necib-prolonge/298975 | title = Necib prolonge | date = 16 July 2012 | work = [[L'Équipe]] | accessdate = 19 July 2012 | language = French}}</ref> On May 21, 2016, Lyon confirmed that Louisa Necib and her friend Lotta Schelin departure the club.
In July 2016, she confirmed that she would end her football career after the [[2016 Summer Olympics]].
==International career==
===Youth=== Nécib is former France women's youth international having played for her nation at every level for which she was eligible. On 11 September 2003, she was called up to international level for the first time by coach Gérard Sergent to play with the under-17 team.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/fem17ans/62866.shtml | title = Les Tricolores retenues en stage | date = 11 September 2003 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> She played with the team at the 2003 edition of the Nordic Cup, a premier women's youth tournament, before earning a call up to the under-19 team by coach [[Bruno Bini]].<ref name="necib_federation">{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/532726.shtml | title = Louisa Necib en quête d'un premier doublé | date = 30 March 2010 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> At under-19 level, Nécib featured heavily playing with the team at the [[La Manga Cup]] and also representing France at the [[2004 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship|2004]] and [[2005 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship|2005]] editions of the [[UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/fem19ans/106532.shtml | title = Les joueuses retenues | date = 1 March 2004 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/fem19ans/117473.shtml | title = La Norvège plie à son tour (3–1) | date = | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the 2004 competition, she appeared in two group stage matches as France suffered elimination in the group stage. In the 2005 edition, Nécib started all five matches France played as the team reached the final. She scored her only goal in the competition in a 4–0 opening group stage victory against [[Russia women's national football team|Russia]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/wunder19/history/season=2005/round=1934/match=81153/index.html | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120716080502/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/wunder19/history/season=2005/round=1934/match=81153/index.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 16 July 2012 | title = Confident France rout Russia | date = 20 July 2005 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref> In the final, France faced their group stage opponents Russia and were defeated 6–5 on penalties after the match finished 2–2 in regulation time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/wunder19/history/season=2005/round=1936/match=81512/index.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120709082303/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/wunder19/history/season=2005/round=1936/match=81512/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=9 July 2012 |title=Russia triumph after shoot-out drama |date=31 July 2005 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=11 September 2011 }}</ref>
Due to France's second-place finish at the 2005 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship, the team qualified for the [[2006 FIFA U-20 Women's World Championship]], which merited under-20 appearances for Nécib. She made her under-20 debut on 12 August 2006 in a World Cup preparation friendly against [[Mexico women's national football team|Mexico]]. In the match, Nécib scored the team's second goal in a 4–2 victory.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.statsfootofeminin.fr/selection/match.php?id=253 | title = Equipe de France des moins de 20 ans – France–Mexique 4–2 | date = 12 August 2006 | work = StatsFootoFeminin | accessdate = 11 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> At the World Cup, Nécib appeared in all four matches France contested. In the team's opening group stage match against [[Argentina women's national football team|Argentina]], she scored the team's third goal in a 5–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=108/edition=10292/matches/match=102920008/report.html | title = France — Argentina | date = 18 August 2006 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref> France suffered elimination in the quarter-finals losing 2–1 to [[North Korea women's national football team|North Korea]].<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=108/edition=10292/matches/match=102920027/report.html | title = North Korea — France | date = 27 August 2006 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref>
===Senior=== [[File:FFWM2011 FRA-GER 20110705 imBorussiapark030.jpg|250px|thumb|left|Nécib, bottom center, ahead of France's match against Germany at the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]].]] Prior to playing at the 2005 UEFA Women's Under-19 Championship, Nécib made her senior international debut on 19 February 2005 in a [[Exhibition match|friendly match]] against [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]]. She started the match and was substituted out after 56 minutes as France won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur_new/match.php?id_match=252 | title = Norvège — France | date = 19 February 2005 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref> The victory was France's first-ever against Norway.<ref name="necib_federation"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/222969.shtml | title = Succès historique face à la Norvège! (2–0) | date = 19 February 2005 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref> Despite featuring in only two senior international matches, the other match being the return leg friendly against Norway on 22 February, Nécib, at the age of 18, was included in the team to play at [[UEFA Women's Euro 2005]] by coach Elisabeth Loisel. The midfielder featured in only one match in the competition; the final group stage match against [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]]. Nécib played the entire match as the Germans won 3–0.<ref name="france_germany">{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/woco/history/season=2005/round=1929/match=80082/index.html | title = German goals end French dreams | date = 12 June 2005 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 11 September 2011 }}</ref> In 2010, Nécib admitted that she took the Germany defeat hard stating "I still have regrets because all we needed was a draw and we conceded three goals in ten minutes".<ref name="necib_federation"/> France had kept the Germans at bay for the majority of the match before letting in three goals in the final 20 minutes.<ref name="france_germany"/>
Following the conclusion of the 2006 U-20 World Cup, Nécib began playing full-time with the senior team participating in [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup qualification|qualification matches]] for the [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup]]. During the season, Nécib also played with the team at the 2006 edition of the [[Algarve Cup]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/289609_la-france-et-le-danemark-se-neutralisent-2-2 | title = La France et le Danemark se neutralisent (2–2) | date = 9 March 2006 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/290398_la-france-bat-la-chine-1-0 | title = La France bat la Chine (1–0) | date = 11 March 2006 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/290564_les-usa-s-imposent-face-aux-bleues-4-1 | title = Les USA s'imposent face aux Bleues (4–1) | date = 13 March 2006 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 22 April 2006, she played with the team in a 5–0 World Cup qualification win against [[Hungary women's national football team|Hungary]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/299529_la-france-s-impose-devant-la-hongrie-5-0 | title = La France s'impose devant la Hongrie (5–0) | date = 22 April 2006 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/wowc/fixturesresults/round=2178/match=80647/report=lu.html |title=Hungary 0–5 France |date=22 April 2006 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708032204/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/wowc/fixturesresults/round%3D2178/match%3D80647/report%3Dlu.html |archivedate=8 July 2007 |df= }}</ref> Afterwards, Nécib failed to appear with the team in its final three qualification matches as France missed the World Cup after drawing 1–1 with [[England women's national football team|England]] in its final qualifying match. France needed an outright victory to qualify for the tournament.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/326841_match-nul-insuffisant-1-1 | title = Match nul insuffisant (1–1) | date = 30 September 2006 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/wowc/fixturesresults/round=2178/match=80988/report=lu.html |title=France 1–1 England |date=30 September 2006 |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104141548/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/wowc/fixturesresults/round%3D2178/match%3D80988/report%3Dlu.html |archivedate=4 January 2007 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:20131031 FR14 Louisa Necib 9332.jpg|thumb|right|Nécib playing for France in a match against [[Austria women's national football team|Austria]] in 2013.]] After the firing of Loisel and the appointment of former youth national team coach [[Bruno Bini]] in 2007, Nécib became a regular starter in the team and, on 11 April 2007, scored her first international goal in a 6–0 victory over [[Greece women's national football team|Greece]] in qualification for [[UEFA Women's Euro 2009]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/370856_belle-entree-en-matiere-6-0 | title = Belle entrée en matière (6–0) | date = 11 April 2007 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> She featured as a starter in all seven qualification matches she appeared in and scored another qualification goal in an 8–0 away win over [[Serbia women's national football team|Serbia]] on 27 October 2007 as France qualified for the competition with one match to spare.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/404013_large-succes-tricolore-8-0 | title = Large succès tricolore (8–0) | date = 27 October 2007 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/465533_les-bleues-a-l-euro-2-1 | title = Les Bleues à l'Euro (2–1) | date = 27 September 2008 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the lead up to UEFA Women's Euro 2009, France participated in the 2009 Cyprus Cup. In the competition, Nécib appeared in three matches and scored the team's second goal in a 3–2 group stage win over [[South Africa women's national football team|South Africa]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/528170_nouveau-succes-face-a-l-afrique-du-sud-3-2 | title = Nouveau succès face à l'Afrique du Sud (3–2) | date = 10 March 2009 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> France later finished the competition in third place. Nécib did not participate in the third-place victory over [[New Zealand women's national football team|New Zealand]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/528202_succes-tricolore-et-troisieme-place | title = Succès tricolore et troisième place | date = 12 March 2009 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> After being selected by Bini to participate in Women's Euro 2009, Nécib scored her fourth international goal in a preparation friendly against [[Scotland women's national football team|Scotland]] on 12 August 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/529960_dernier-test-gagnant-4-0 | title = Dernier test gagnant (4–0) | date = 12 August 2009 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In her second major competition for France, Nécib started all four of the team's matches. She scored her first major international goal in the team's opening group stage match against [[Iceland women's national football team|Iceland]] netting the final goal in a 3–1 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/woco/fixturesresults/round=15046/match=304287/index.html | title = France hit the spot against Iceland | date = 24 August 2009 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> France reached the quarter-finals before suffering elimination losing on penalties to the [[Netherlands women's national football team|Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/woco/fixturesresults/round=15047/match=2001417/index.html | title = Oranje through after shoot-out | date = 3 September 2009 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref>
Following Women's Euro 2009, Nécib returned to the national team duty to participate in [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup qualification (UEFA)|qualification]] for the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup]]. In qualification, she participated in nine of the ten qualifying round group stage matches France contested. France finished the stage winning all of its matches and conceding no goals. Nécib scored two goals during the round against [[Estonia women's national football team|Estonia]] in a 12–0 win and [[Northern Ireland women's national football team|Northern Ireland]] in a 6–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womensworldcup/matches/season=2011/round=2000048/match=2000984/index.html | title = France v. Estonia Match Report | date = 28 October 2009 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womensworldcup/matches/season=2011/round=2000048/match=2000982/index.html | title = France v. Northern Ireland Match Report | date = 27 March 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> In September 2010, she played in both legs of France's World Cup playoff match against [[Italy women's national football team|Italy]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womensworldcup/matches/season=2011/round=2000049/match=2003213/report/index.html | title = Stubborn Italy frustrate France | date = 11 September 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> France won the tie 3–2 on aggregate to qualify for its second [[FIFA Women's World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.uefa.com/womensworldcup/matches/season=2011/round=2000049/match=2003217/report/index.html | title = France see off Italy to reach World Cup | date = 15 September 2010 | work = [[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> On 19 November 2010, Nécib scored her first international double in a 5–0 friendly win over [[Poland women's national football team|Poland]].<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/535681_les-bleues-s-imposent-5-0 | title = Les Bleues s'imposent (5–0) | date = 19 November 2010 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> After playing in the [[2011 Cyprus Cup]] and several friendly matches, on 6 June 2011, Nécib was named to the 21-woman squad to participate in the World Cup.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.fff.fr/selections/femininesa/actu/537799_la-liste-devoilee | title = La liste dévoilée | date = 6 June 2011 | work = [[French Football Federation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 18 June, in a prep friendly against [[Belgium women's national football team|Belgium]], she scored her tenth international goal in a 7–0 home win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fff.fr/compint/66507/match/66541.shtml |title=Les Bleues impressionnent |date=18 June 2011 |work=[[French Football Federation]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720085444/http://www.fff.fr/compint/66507/match/66541.shtml |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
On 26 June 2011, in France's opening World Cup group stage match against [[Nigeria women's national football team|Nigeria]], Nécib, on her competition's debut, was named the ''Player of the Match'' for her performance in the team's 1–0 victory.<ref name="necib_ray">{{cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/news/newsid=1462829/index.html |title=Necib, France's ray of sunshine |date=27 June 2011 |work=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701174907/http://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/news/newsid%3D1462829/index.html |archivedate=1 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255997/match=300144432/report.html | title = Nigeria — France | date = 26 June 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> In the team's second group stage match against [[Canada women's national soccer team|Canada]], she assisted on the final goal, scored by Thomis, in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255997/match=300144434/report.html | title = Canada — France | date = 30 June 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/huff-wires/20110630/soc-wwcup-france-canada/ | title = France routs Canada 4–0 at women's World Cup | date = 30 June 2011 | work = [[Huffington Post]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> Nécib started France's final four matches in the competition, which included a 4–2 loss against Germany in the team final group stage match and a 4–3 penalty shootout victory over England in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255997/match=300144443/report.html | title = France — Germany | date = 5 July 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255995/match=300144433/report.html | title = England — France | date = 9 July 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> France were eliminated from the competition in the semi-finals losing 3–1 to the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]] after goals from [[Abby Wambach]] and [[Alex Morgan]] broke a 1-1 deadlock created when [[Sonia Bompastor]] had equalized following Lauren Cheney's opener.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255993/match=300144449/report.html | title = France — USA | date = 13 July 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> On 16 July, in the third place match against [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden]], Nécib was forced to leave the match after 30 minutes due to an injury, a sprained knee who forced her to leave the stadium on crutches.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-07-16/sports/chi-world-cup-sweden-tops-france-21-for-third-place-20110716_1_lotta-schelin-hedvig-lindahl-louisa-necib | title = World Cup: Sweden tops France 2–1 for third place | date = 16 July 2011 | work = [[Chicago Tribune]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> France lost 2–1.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/matches/round=255991/match=300144446/report.html | title = Sweden — France | date = 16 July 2011 | work = [[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> During and after the competition, Nécib was praised for her performance by several media outlets with one publication declaring that she "was largely responsible for France making it the semifinals in the first place".<ref name="necib_cbc"/><ref name="necib_ray"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700148580/Germany-wins-but-France-sparkling-at-Womens-World-Cup.html | title = Germany wins, but France sparkling at Women's World Cup | date = 1 July 2011 | work = Deseret News | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/fifawomensworldcup2011/story/2011/07/04/sp-group-a-finale.html | title = 1st place up for grabs in Group A | date = 4 July 2011 | work = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref>
==Style of play== {{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote= "Louisa is a player that there are few of. What she does, it's not in the textbooks. She is an artist. It's sunny when she touches the ball. She radiates the team." |source= <small>[[France women's national football team|National team]] coach [[Bruno Bini]] on Nécib's style of play.<ref name="necib_20minutes"/></small> }} Nécib primarily plays as an [[attacking midfielder]], but can also be deployed in [[central midfielder|central midfield]] as a [[deep-lying playmaker|deep-lying midfielder]], or as a [[Winger (association football)|winger]]. Domestically, she primarily plays as a [[playmaker]] in the number 10 role, while at international level, she plays as a winger in Bruno Bini's 4–3–3 formation. Two of Nécib's most common exemplary traits are her vision and passing, which have been described as "one-of-a-kind" and "sublime", respectively.<ref name="necib_cbc"/><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.sportsbookgurus.com/news/womens-world-cup-game-preview-germany-a-favorite-over-france | title = Women's World Cup Game Preview: Germany A Favorite Over France | date = 5 July 2011 | work = Sportsbook Gurus | accessdate = 12 September 2011 }}</ref> She is also known for her distinct understanding of the game, which has led to her developing "a great football IQ".<ref name="necib_cbc"/> In addition to her creativity, eye for goal, and tactical awareness, she is known for outstanding control and [[Dribbling#Association football|dribbling]] ability, as well as her elegance on the ball.<ref name="necib_fifa"/><ref name="necib_cbc"/> Her technical skill and ability to read the game allow her to determine "when to take a defender on one-on-one, how to find a teammate with a slide-rule pass, and how to exploit tight spaces to create scoring chances for herself and her cohorts".<ref name="necib_cbc"/> For these reasons, her playing style has drawn comparisons with compatriot and 1998 World Cup winner Zinedine Zidane.<ref name="necib_laprovence2"/>
